task.title: Uploading files
task.shortdesc: These instructions can be used for any file upload or born digital documents.

taskbody.prereq: Navigate to or create the subcollection in which you want to upload your file. This can be in your research space or within a project.

step.cmd: Click on Add a new object to this collection.
Choose the Content Model that your object belongs in. Click Next.
step.info: You can upload any type of object into your CWRC collection, but your collection policies must support what you are uploading. To see if your collection has the policy necessary for the file you are uploading see “Changing the collection policy of a collection.”

step.cmd: Select the bibliographical form that you require. Click on Next.
step.info: The options found in the form depends on what you are uploading, the image below is there when you upload a “Basic Image.” The Book form is good if you are transcribing a primary text or want bibliographical fields primarily related to a monograph.

step.cmd: Fill in the MODS record with the appropriate information. Click on Next.
step.info: As with all MODS records, all that is required is a title. You can always come back and add more links to related entities, topics, genres, etc.

step.cmd: Choose the object you would like to upload by clicking on the “Browse” button.
step.info: The file formats available to upload are listed beneath the Browse button.

step.cmd: Once you have chosen a file, click on Upload.
Click Ingest to finish uploading the object to your CWRC Collection.

link.desc: CWRC is an online research environment that brings together scholarly materials and digital tools.

When you upload files into CWRC you must have a place to put them. You need subcollections or “folders” that will organize the files within a project (or “collection”). Each subcollection is assigned a policy which determines which type of files are allowed to be stored in them.

If you would like to upload a particular object to your collection, you may have to change the policy associated with your collection (depending on what you assigned to it when you created your collection).

The organization, creation, and upload of materials relies on content models. These define the parameters of a subcollection, determining is you can add a subcollection and what type of material can be added.

CWRC users have different levels of access to their projects. This ranges from non-members who can only view the materials on CWRC to project administrators who has complete control over project materials.

CWRC provides an enriched user experience no matter what type of user account you have. Features include an insite messaging system between project members and a bookmarking tool to collection your favorite materials together.
CWRC utilizes a robust search system to make the contents of the site as accessible and explorable as possible.

task.title: Searching CWRC
task.shortdesc: CWRC provides users with a search and advanced search functions. Searchable items include projects, collection, files and topics of interest.

step.cmd: Enter your search term in the search box at the top of the page.
step.info: You can narrow down where the search results come from, using the drop down menu. The options are: the project you are currently located in, the entire collaboratory or all website content.

step.cmd: Click on the search icon.
If you would like to narrow down your search results, you can use the Advanced Search feature.
step.info: The Advanced Search function provides the opportunity to have multiple fields and search terms. Click on the red plus button to get more options. These are separated by Boolean operators (AND, OR, and NOT).

step.cmd: Click on Search.
Explore your search results.
step.info: If you have multiple search results you can use the faceted browsing features along the left side of the results. These filters narrow down the search results by category. For more information about browsing CWRC see Searching and Browsing Reference.

link.desc: CWRC is an online research environment that brings together scholarly materials and digital tools.

CWRC has a bookmarking feature so that you can access files across projects quickly. Additionally you can use your bookmark lists in the visualization tool PlotIt (for more information see Using PlotIt in CWRC )
To organize your bookmarks you can create separate lists for them. This also allows you to describe what the list includes.
CWRC utilizes a robust search system to make the contents of the site as accessible and explorable as possible.

How you view files in CWRC depends on the file itself. XML documents are viewed in the visualization tool CWRC-Writer. Image, audio, video, and document files open within your browser. For more information see Content Models Reference.

The organization, creation, and upload of materials relies on content models. These define the parameters of a subcollection, determining is you can add a subcollection and what type of material can be added.

CWRC users have different levels of access to their projects. This ranges from non-members who can only view the materials on CWRC to project administrators who has complete control over project materials.

CWRC provides an enriched user experience no matter what type of user account you have. Features include an insite messaging system between project members and a bookmarking tool to collection your favorite materials together.

task.title: Report a bug
task.shortdesc: CWRC is still in development and you may discover some bugs. Please let us know if you find an issue.

step.cmd: Click on the question mark icon in the top right corner.
Click on Report a Bug.
Fill out the Report a Bug form.
step.info: Please provide as much detail as possible. This will help our programmers to easily find, reproduce and fix the bug.

step.cmd: Click Submit.

task.title: Edit your user profile
task.shortdesc: When you are approved for a CWRC account, only your name, email and password are attached to said account. Adding account details (like an image) make your account more accessible and findable for other members.

step.cmd: Login to your account.
Click on the Edit tab.
Edit your account information.
step.info: Options include uploading an image, a bio text box, setting your language preference, changing your password, setting your time zone, and adding a website.

step.cmd: Click Save.

link.desc: CWRC is an online research environment that brings together scholarly materials and digital tools.
CWRC provides a customizable user experience for members. Members of CWRC can upload, edit and explore digital texts.

Once you have a CWRC account, you can request to join different participating projects. Project content is available to view if you are not a member, but (depending to the file lock) you may not be able to edit or annotate.

task.title: Adding a bookmark
task.shortdesc: CWRC has a bookmarking feature so that you can access files across projects quickly. Additionally you can use your bookmark lists in the visualization tool PlotIt (for more information see Using PlotIt in CWRC )

taskbody.prereq: You need to be logged in to your CWRC account to add bookmarks.

step.cmd: Select the object you would like to bookmark.
step.info: CWRC lets users bookmark subcollections (or folders) or individual files. What you bookmark depends on what you have open when you click on the Add to Bookmark button. For example, the screenshot below will add only that particular file to your bookmark list.

step.cmd: Select the bookmark list you would like to add this bookmark to.
Click on Add to Bookmark.

link.desc: CWRC is an online research environment that brings together scholarly materials and digital tools.
To organize your bookmarks you can create separate lists for them. This also allows you to describe what the list includes.
CWRC has the option to share or make your bookmark lists private. Bookmark lists are private as the default. The same steps apply if you would like to make a bookmark list private.
You can use the visualization tool, PlotIt, in CWRC. This feature works with your bookmark lists to map and date the files that you have bookmarked. For more information about using PlotIt, see

task.title: Adding bookmark lists
task.shortdesc: To organize your bookmarks you can create separate lists for them. This also allows you to describe what the list includes.

step.cmd: Login to your account.
Under the Bookmark tab on the right side of your dashboard page, click on New List.
step.info: The expanded bookmark tab displays all the lists that you have (initially just a “workbench” list) and the lists that are shared with you.

step.cmd: Fill out the Bookmark list form.
Click Add List.

task.title: Sharing your Bookmark lists
task.shortdesc: CWRC has the option to share or make your bookmark lists private. Bookmark lists are private as the default. The same steps apply if you would like to make a bookmark list private.

step.cmd: From your dashboard, click on the bookmark list you would like to share.
Select the user you would like to share your bookmark list with.
step.info: You can choose to share your list with everyone or with individual users. If you chooses to share with only a few members you must manually select them.

step.cmd: Click on Share.

Click on the Bookmark List tab on the right side of the page.
Select the bookmark list that you would like to visualize in PlotIt.

step.cmd: Open the collection that has the item you would like to view.
Click on the file.
step.info: The images below show two different way you can view files in CWRC. The first is an XML file shown in CWRC-Writer. The second is a video file displayed within its CWRC file page.

task.title: Sharing/Migrating Objects
task.shortdesc: The sharing options CWRC provides depend on if you are trying to share a file or a folder. Folders can be shared to different social media sites (Facebook, etc.), while individual files can be shared to those sites as well as different CWRC projects.

step.cmd: Open the file or folder that you would like to share.
Click on the Share tab above the file or folder.
Choose the site you would like to share the folder/file with.
If you are sharing with your a social media account, sign in and share the file with your friends/followers.
step.info:
The two options,“Share with another collection” and “Migrate to another collection,” are conditional to your own projects. For example, you can not migrate another projects document to your own project.
The Facebook, Twitter, and Google Plus options will require you to sign in to your account.

step.cmd: If you choose to “Share with another collection,” enter the filename and click Share Object.
If you choose to “Migrate to another collection,” enter the new collection name (or the destination collection name). Click on Migrate Object.

task.title: View Project Homepages
task.shortdesc: Project homepages display the project's description and can include a link to the entire collection, featured items from the collection, external links to the project's website and/or social media page, list of sponsors, director(s) names, as well as an About Me page that lists the project's contact information.

context.note: Projects are created by CWRC administrators, who assign associated members of CWRC the role of Project Editor to enable them to edit their project pages. Projects must be approved by the CWRC Research Board. If you wish to propose a project please fill out the application form.

step.cmd: Open CWRC in your browser. Link here.
Select login. Enter in your Username and password.
step.info: Access to login is located on the top right corner of the browser.

step.cmd: You will be directed to the view page for your user profile, where you can see Projects I belong to. Among the items in this list, select the project that you wish to access.
step.info: This will redirect you to the Project Homepage. The title of the project should display near the top of the page.

task.shortdesc: Project homepages display the project's description and can include a link to the entire collection, featured items from the collection, external links to the project's website and/or social media page, list of sponsors, director(s) names, as well as an About Me page that lists the project's contact information.

context.note: Projects are created by CWRC administrators, who assign associated members of CWRC the role of Project Editor to enable them to edit their project pages. Projects must be approved by the CWRC Research Board. If you wish to propose a project please fill out the application form.

step.cmd: Open CWRC in your browser.
Access to login is located on the top right corner of the browser. Select login, and enter in your Username and Password
You will be directed to the view page for your user profile, where you can see Projects I belong to. Among the items in this list, select the project that you wish to access.
This will redirect you to the Project Homepage. The title of the project should display near the top of the page.
step.info: Projects are created by CWRC administrators, who assign associated members of CWRC the role of Project Editor to enable them to edit their project pages. Projects must be approved by the CWRC Research Board. If you wish to propose a project please fill out the application form at the following link.

task.title: Making Changes to Project Homepages
task.shortdesc: Project homepages display the project's description and can include a link to the entire collection, featured items from the collection, external links to the project's website and/or social media page, list of sponsors, director(s) names, as well as an About Me page that lists the project's contact information.

context.note: Projects are created by CWRC administrators, who assign associated members of CWRC the role of Project Editor to enable them to edit their project pages. Projects must be approved by the CWRC Research Board. If you wish to propose a project please fill out the application form.

step.cmd: To change the homepage, begin by clicking Project Dashboard. This gives you access to some of the most important actions and information associated with a project.
From the sidebar on the right, you can see the various editing features listed under Utilities.

For making changes to your homepage, the three options – Add Page to Project, Edit Project Menu, and Edit Project Settings – are the utilities that will be further discussed in detail. All of these options are located under Utilities on theProject Dashbard page.

info.p: The Project Dashboard can be accessed by selecting the Project Dashboard button (on the top left, under the project title). On this page you'll find a list of Recent Workflow Stamps, Locked Objects, Utilities, Project Members, Pending Applications, Workflow Reports, Disk Quota, and Credit Visualizations.

step.cmd: Edit/Edit project settings allows you to make changes to basic information, identity and social media, contact information, sponsors, and featured content.

info.p: The Edit button on the action bar and Edit project settings on the Utility menu (on the right) perform the same function and take you to the same screen.

step.cmd: If you'd like to save the edits you'e made to the project homepage, it is important to remember to scroll down and click Save before leaving the page.

link.desc: Once you have a CWRC account, you can request to join different participating projects. Project content is available to view if you are not a member, but (depending to the file lock) you may not be able to edit or annotate.

task.title: Messaging project members

taskbody.prereq: You need to be logged in to your CWRC account to send messages.

step.cmd: Click on the bell icon, located in the top right corner of CWRC.
step.info: Clicking on the bell icon takes you to your message inbox.

step.cmd: Click on the New Messages button.
Fill out the new message form.
step.info: To send to other users you need to enter their user name, however CWRC provides drop down menu of user names based on what you begin to type (see screenshot below).

step.cmd: To preview your message click on Preview Message .
Click on Send Message . You will get a banner notification that your message was sent.

When you are approved for a CWRC account, only your name, email and password are attached to said account. Adding account details (like an image) make your account more accessible and findable for other members.

CWRC users have different levels of access to their projects. This ranges from non-members who can only view the materials on CWRC to project administrators who has complete control over project materials.

CWRC provides an enriched user experience no matter what type of user account you have. Features include an insite messaging system between project members and a bookmarking tool to collection your favorite materials together.
CWRC utilizes a robust search system to make the contents of the site as accessible and explorable as possible.

reference.title: Welcome to CWRC-Writer
reference.shortdesc: Welcome to CWRC-Writer. In this page we describe how to get started using the editor and what to look out for.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

section.title: Introduction to getting started in CWRC-Writer
section.p: To get started in CWRC-Writer, we suggest familiarizing yourself with the editor in a sample document first, and then moving on to trying to create a new document if you wish.
section.note:
Please, handle with care:
For the moment, CWRC-Writer is optimized for Firefox and Chrome.
Allow CWRC-Writer a few seconds to load each page. If you interrupt the loading process you may have to shut down and reopen CWRC_Writer to continue working with this tool. You can open a saved document or a new template using the "Load" button on the toolbar. The CWRC logo in the upper left corner will take you outside the CWRC-Writer to the CWRC website (www.cwrc.ca). The new entity data option VIAF and GeoNames also take a few seconds to load. Thank you for your patience.
Chrome: https://support.google.com/chrome/answer/95582?hl=en
Firefox: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-clear-firefox-cache
If the problem persists, please email cwrc@ualberta.ca If you are having problems with CWRC-Writer, please clear your browser cache. If the problem persists, please email cwrc@ualberta.ca

link.desc: There are multiple ways to begin writing text in CWRC-Writer. You can select a tag and then begin to write, or you can place your cursor in the editor and begin to type.

CWRC-Writer allows you to save documents you have created on our server as temporary test files to work with.
The validation of your XML document against the associated schema. If your document is invalid a list of errors found in the document will appear at the bottom of the page.
There is an option to change the different editor modes for your document. Editor modes control what tagging will be allowed in your document (a combination of XML and RDF).
Show tags allows you to view all the XML tags in the document.
Edit Source is for users who wish to edit the raw XML or RDF code. We do not suggest that you use this option unless you are an expert.
You can edit the TEI header in CWRC-Writer.

reference.title: Working with CWRC-Writer in CWRC
reference.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer provides three options for users to work with their documents. Users can view, annotate or edit documents.

section.title: General Description
section.p: CWRC-Writer provides three options for users to work with their documents. Users can view, annotate or edit documents.

When working with your document in the Annotation or Edit options other people cannot work with the document. If the document is locked (you don’t have permission to work with) or someone is currently working with the document you will be unable to “Annotate” or “Edit” and receive error messages.
If you are finished editing or annotating choose the “Save and Exit” option, this then frees up the document for other team members, so that they may work with it.

section.title: Viewing a document in CWRC-Writer
section.p: CWRC-Writer provides a viewing option so that users can look at locked documents (those that are not available to edit or annotate). This is the default view when users open CWRC-Writer.
While in view mode CWRC-Writer does not allow you to change or add tags to the document.

section.title: Annotating a document
section.p: This option allows users to work with the RDF in the document. You can add RDF annotations (person, place, organization, etc.) using the toolbar.
If the document is unavailable to be annotated or someone is currently working with the document you will be unable to “Annotate” your document and you will receive an error message.

section.title: Editing your document
section.p: This allows users to edit the content and tags of the document.

task.title: Annotating your document
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer provides users with the opportunity to annotate documents. This feature is only available to users who are in the same project as the document or if the document is unlocked.

step.cmd: Click on the "Annotate" tab.
step.info: You cannot annotate your document if someone else is editing/annotating it or if it is locked (unavailable to non project members). You will see error messages (and you will remain on “View” mode).

step.cmd: Begin to annotate your document by adding person, place, organization (etc.) entities to it.
Click on “Save” or “Save and exit” if you are done annotating your document.

task.title: Creating a document
task.shortdesc: To create CWRC-Writer compatible documents you can either upload well formed XML files or create a document from existing templates.

taskbody.prereq: The folders collection policy needs to have the matching content model for what you are creating or uploading. For more information see link

step.cmd: In your project folder click on the “Manage” tab.
Click on “Add item.”
This brings you to the page where you need to select your content model. For XML documents choose "CWRC Document Content Model."
You then need to select a form for your document.
step.info: We suggest you to use the "CWRC born digital" for uploading XML or creating a document from a template (unless you are uploading a book).

step.cmd: This brings you to a form that lets you add information about the document you are either uploading or creating.
step.info: The only required field is the title.

step.cmd: Click on next button at the bottom of the form.
This is where you choose to either upload a file or begin from a template. Choose your option.
If you have selected to upload from file, click on “Browse.”

substep.cmd: Once you have found your document click on “Open.”

substep.info: Any documents that you are uploading must be well formed XML and end in .xml. If the document is not a “well formed XML” document or does not have the .xml file name extension then you cannot upload it.

substep.cmd: Select your document schema from the dropdown menu.
Click on “Ingest” and begin to work with your document.

step.cmd: If you have selected to open a template, click on the template option.

substep.cmd: Choose the type of template you would like to work with.
substep.info: The templates are already associated with schemas so you do not have to select one.

substep.cmd: Click on “Ingest” and begin to work with your document.

step.cmd: Click on the tag that contains the text you would like to delete.
Right-click on the selected tag and choose Remove Content Only

taskbody.result:
This will remove the content from this tag, but it will leave the tag in the document.
If you would like to delete the tag and the content, choose Remove tag and all content option from the right-click menu.

task.title: Saving your document
task.shortdesc: In CWRC-Writer your documents can be edited by multiple people. The “Save and Exit” icon does as the title suggests and opens up the document for others to edit.

step.cmd: Edit or Annotate your document.
Once you have completed any changes you wish to make to the document click on the toolbar option to Save.
Once you clicked on Save, the document validates and is successfully saved.
step.info: If the document is not valid, a pop-up will appear and you will be asked if you would like to save anyway.

step.cmd: If you would like to leave CWRC-Writer after saving your document, choose the Save and Exit option.

step.cmd: Click on the Save toolbar button.
Enter the title of the document, and click Save.
step.info: Adding your initials to the beginning (e.g. MS) is a good way to indicate to others that it is a file created by another CWRC-Writer tester. You may only enter upper or lowercase letter; no numbers, spaces, or punctuation are allowed. At the moment, we do not have individual authentication setup for each user, so it's best if you do not play with each other's files: this way each tester can have his/her own files to alter, add to, and so forth.

step.cmd: Once you clicked on Save, the document validates and is successfully saved.
step.info: If the document is not valid, a pop-up will appear and you will be asked if you would like to save anyway.

step.cmd: Click on the Validate button on the toolbar.
step.stepresult: If the document is invalid a pop-up appears with error messages.

step.cmd: Click on one of the errors, this will highlight the error in the document. You can then correct the invalid structure.
step.info: You can still save the document if it is invalid, but a pop-up will appear making sure that you want to proceed.

step.cmd: Validate again.

taskbody.result: If you fixed all the validation errors, you should receive a confirmation message.

task.shortdesc: There is an option to change the different editor modes for your document. Editor modes control what tagging will be allowed in your document (a combination of XML and RDF).

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the Settings button on the top right top of the editor

Select your preferred editor mode from the drop-down menu and click on OK. This will change the editor mode for your document. There are three editor modes in CWRC-Writer, based on the treatment of overlap.
step.info: The default mode is XML and RDF - no overlap. You can change the editor mode in your document at any time (NOTE: If you have overlapping entities and are attempting to switch to a mode which prohibits them. The overlapping entities will be discarded if you switch modes).

Click on the document/template you would like to open from the pop-up list.

taskbody.result: By selecting a document/template from the list in the pop-up a new page will be reloaded. If you have not saved your information prior to opening a different document you will lose any changes that you have made.

CWRC-Writer allows you to save documents you have created on our server as temporary test files to work with.
The validation of your XML document against the associated schema. If your document is invalid a list of errors found in the document will appear at the bottom of the page.

reference.title: CWRC-Writer features
reference.shortdesc: The reference materials available explain, in detail, components of CWRC-Writer.

section.title: Introduction to reference materials
section.p: The reference materials available explain, in detail, components of CWRC-Writer. For example, you can use the documents linked to below, to understand how the three panels on the left work, or which right-click menus are available in each section of the editor.

link.desc: The "Settings" options allow you to change the settings of your document.

You can create CWRC-Writer documents in two ways, either by uploading a file or by using a pre existing template (provided by CWRC). Additionally, these options are customizable to you and your project because you select which schema to use.
There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.
At the top of the editor there is a toolbar that allows you to add, edit, and delete tags and entities.
The editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.
You can add tags within the editor by highlighting the text and right-clicking. This will bring up a list of option available to you (adding entities, structural tags, editing, etc).
CWRC-Writer provides two options to save your changes and document. The first is a general save action, but the second allows users to save and then exit the document.

reference.title: Creating documents
reference.shortdesc: You can create CWRC-Writer documents in two ways, either by uploading a file or by using a pre existing template (provided by CWRC). Additionally, these options are customizable to you and your project because you select which schema to use.

section.title: General information
section.p: To upload a document you need to first create a folder in CWRC (please see instruction here ). Then choose to to add a new document in the folder by clicking on the “Manage tab”

Users have the option to either upload a document from file or open a template provided by CWRC. When following the steps to create a CWRC-Writer document you have the option to add more information about the document you are creating, though the only required information is the object's title.

section.title: Upload from file
section.p: Any documents that you are uploading must be well formed XML and end in .xml. If the document is not a “well formed XML” document or does not have the .xml file name extension then you cannot upload it.
You can customize your document by choosing the schema it follows from an drop down menu.

section.title: From a template
section.p: Templates are already available from CWRC and Orlando, and are “well formed” XML documents. Templates are stored in the CWRC Document Template Collection. Additionally, these templates already have an associated schema attached (making it easier for XML beginners).

link.desc: The reference materials available explain, in detail, components of CWRC-Writer.
The "Settings" options allow you to change the settings of your document.
There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.
At the top of the editor there is a toolbar that allows you to add, edit, and delete tags and entities.
The editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.
You can add tags within the editor by highlighting the text and right-clicking. This will bring up a list of option available to you (adding entities, structural tags, editing, etc).
CWRC-Writer provides two options to save your changes and document. The first is a general save action, but the second allows users to save and then exit the document.

reference.title: Settings menu
reference.shortdesc: The "Settings" options allow you to change the settings of your document.

section.title: Settings menu - general information
section.p: The settings menu is located in the top right corner of the editor.

The top half of the settings pop-up allows users to modify the font and size of the text displayed in the editor panel. There are two check boxes that allow you to view the entity brackets (which is preset to be on) and the show tags option. This will allow you to view the XML brackets in the document.
We advise you to make both entities and tags visible by checking the two options listed below, especially if you intend to work a lot with tags and entities.
The lower half of the Settings pop-up allows users to select the editor mode and the schema associated with the current document (see more below).
Currently, when you select Add Schema a pop-up appears. This allows you to add your Schema Name and Schema URL. Once you have filled in those fields, click on Add Schema.

Now your schema is set in the drop-down menu. Use this feature carefully! When you upload your XML document into CWR you must select your document schema. Any changes to your schema may impact your document.

section.title: Settings menu - changing the editor mode
section.p: You can change the editor mode in your document at any time (NOTE: If you have overlapping entities and are attempting to switch to a mode which prohibits them, your document will not be valid). This changes the flexibility of tags and entities within your document.

XML or eXtensible Markup Language is a markup language that allows both humans and computers to read the tags. RDF or Resource Description Framework is part of the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) that allows human to tag words in phrases in a markup language.

The main difference between these two forms or markup languages are that RDF allows the user to overlap tags. For example, "Leonardo da Vinci" is both the name of a famous artist and a place, so in mark up it would look something like this: <"Name">Leonardo da<"Place">Vinci<"/Place"><"/Name">. XML does not allow the user to overlap tags so that only the "Name" tag could be used. To change between XML and RDF the user has to go to the Settings button in the top right corner.

li.p: If you are in the XML no overlap mode then the annotations added using editor's entity buttons will be saved as the equivalent tags within your schema, with the entity data stored in the tags attributes as far as the schema allows; the same entity annotations can also be saved in the for of RDF.

In the XML/RDF no overlap mode the entities will be saved in the form of RDF only, although the structural tags for your document will continue to take the form of hierarchical XML. However, you cannot overlap the tags and entities.

ul.li: If you are in XML/RDF overlapping entities mode then your entities will be saved in the for of RDF only, although the structural tags for your document will continue to take the form of hierarchical XML. You can add tags and entities to the document that overlap within the document.
In the RDF only mode, you can annotate the document (adding tags such as person, place, organization, etc.) with RDF. There will be not XML structure attachted to the document.

reference.title: Navigation panels
reference.shortdesc: There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.

section.title: Structure panel
section.p: The structure panel displays the XML markup of the document. From here you can add, delete, edit, and copy and paste tags in the document.

In the structure panel, deleting a tag will delete both the tag and text content. A double click selects the content of the tag and deleting will delete only the text (more text can then be typed to replace it).

section.title: Entities panel
section.p: The entities panel lets users see the entities that they have tagged in the document (date, organization, title, etc). You may view the items in this tab either sequentially or by category.

section.title: Relations panel
section.p: In the relations panel you may view any relationships, which you have established between entities. You can establish relationships through the Add Relations button in the toolbar at the top of the page or at the bottom of this panel. You can also delete relations at the bottom of the panel.

reference.title: CWRC-Writer Toolbar
reference.shortdesc: At the top of the editor there is a toolbar that allows you to add, edit, and delete tags and entities.

ul.li: Tag Menu is where you go to find and apply the structural tags.
Tag Person is for tagging people by name. It usually contains a proper noun or noun phrase, but can also contain pronouns or other ways of referring to someone.
Tag Place is for tagging a place. It can describe both a geographical location or setting.
Tag Date is for tagging a date in the text. This tag can contain the year, month, day or a combination of the three.
Tag Organization is used to tag and organization or company.

Tag Citation is for tagging citations in the text, which may contain a loosely structured bibliographic citation of which the subcomponents may or may not be explicitly tagged. When using this option a mini-editor pops up.
Tag Note is used to tag a note or annotation. When using this option a mini-editor pops up.
Tag Text/Title is for tagging a title or the text of any type of work.
Tag Correction is used to tag any correction you have made to the original text.
Tag Keyword is for tagging any important keywords in your document.
Tag Link is for tagging any links or URLs found in the document.
Edit Tag is used to edit a tag that you have created in CWRC-Writer, by changing the information assigned to the tag.
Remove Tag is for removing any unwanted tags.

Add Relation is for creating relationships between tags. You can create relationships between the tags for Person, Place, Date, Event, Organization, Citation, Note, and Title. When users create a relationship they will be asked to specify how the two tags are related, for example are two different "Person tags" family, or collaborators.
Edit Source is for users who wish to edit the raw XML or RDF code. We do not suggest that you use this option unless you are an expert.
W3C Validate is a useful tool that allows users to validate their XML tags by the standards of the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C).
Save is for saving any changes you have made to your already saved documents.
Save and Exit this will save any changes you have made to the document and exit you from CWRC-Writer.

link.desc: The reference materials available explain, in detail, components of CWRC-Writer.
The "Settings" options allow you to change the settings of your document.
There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.
The editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.
CWRC-Writer provides two options to save your changes and document. The first is a general save action, but the second allows users to save and then exit the document.
Tagging RDF annotated entities in CWRC-Writer allows users to add semantic information to certain text (person, place, etc).
The CWRC-Writer allows editors of documents to mark up or embed semantic tags in documents using Extensible Markup Language (XML).

reference.title: CWRC Entity system
reference.shortdesc: The editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.

section.title: Understanding the CWRC entity system
section.p: The editor is now hooked up to the CWRC entity system. Lookup of all named entities (i.e. person,s, organizations, places, and titles) from within CWRC is now available, as well as lookup in the authoritative linked data sources.

The external VIAF list of authorities, produced from national and major research libraries around the world, is used to link persons, organizations and titles, while GeoNames and GoogleGeocode are employed in a similar capacity for place entities. More such authoritative sources will be added in future.
Once you click on Select a popup appears where you can add additional attributes to the entity. For example, you can declare if the person is real, fictional or both.

It is now possible to add a new entity to the CWRC collection if the person/organization/place/title you are tagging is not found in either of these sets. From the entity lookup pop-up, you can click on the button to create a new entity and you will be taken to a pop-up that allows you to enter the appropriate information. Once created, the new entity will be a reference in your tag/annotations and thereafter you will be able to select it from the CWRC entity list for future tags/annotations.

This new feature of CWRC Writer allows you to seamlessly integrate your documents with the semantic web, which is described in more detail in the documents reference below. To avoid ambiguities when tagging named entities, you can also look up and see exactly what linked data you are adding to your document. Clicking on the small black information circle beside an entity option creates a pop-up with a URL. If you open that URL in a new tab you can now see exactly what information you are adding to your document.
For more information on the lookups available in CWRC-Writer, see the links below.
VIAF: https://viaf.org
GeoNames: http://www.geonames.org
GoogleGeocode: https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/geocoding/

reference.title: CWRC-Writer right-click menus
reference.shortdesc: You can add tags within the editor by highlighting the text and right-clicking. This will bring up a list of option available to you (adding entities, structural tags, editing, etc).

section.title: Right click menu in the text area

p.lines: Tag Person is for tagging people by name. It usually contains a proper noun or noun phrase, but can also contain pronouns or other ways of referring to someone.
Tag Place is for tagging a place. It can describe both a geographical location or a setting.
Tag Date is for tagging a date in the text. This tag can contain the year, month, day, or a combination of the three.
Tag Organization is used to tag an organization or company.
Tag Citation is for tagging citations in the text, which may contain a loosely structured bibliographic citation of which the subcomponents may or may not be explicitly tagged.
Tag Note is used to tag a note or annotations.
Tag Text/Title is for tagging a title or the text of any type of work.
Tag Correction is used to tag any errors in the text and add a correction to it.
Tag Keyword is used to tag keywords.
Tag Link is used to tag URLs.
Structural Tags allows you to add XML tags to the highlighted text. You can filter tags using the search field at the top of the list.
Change Tag this allows you to change a tag (for example, turn a "lg" - line group - into a "p" - paragraph).
Edit Tag this allows you to edit a tag by modifying the attributes of the tag.
Split Tags is used to split a tag (e.g. seperating a paragraph to form two paragraphs).
Remove Tag is for removing a tag.
Copy Tag and Contents allows you to copy the tag and all the content (text) it contains.
Paste Tag lets users paste in a tag (and its content if copied).
Convert to entity appears only when you select a tag that is also a RDF annotation (like note, person, place, etc.). It will change the tag from the XML to RDF.
Copy Entity allows you to copy an entity, this option is only available when you highlight a pre tagged entity.
Paste Entity allows you to paste in a copied entity (to move or duplicate a note entity for example).

refbody.section:
Right-click menu in the structure column
In CWRC-Writer, you can add tags through the structure panel on the left side of the editor. To add tags in the structure panel, select a tag and then right-click. this will bring up a menu with eight options that allow you to either insert a tag, edit an existing tag, or remove tags. Convert to entity appears only when you select a tag that is also a RDF annotation (like note, person, place, etc.). It will change the tag from the XML to RDF.Insert Tag Before allows you to insert a tag before the tag you have right-clicked on.Insert Tag After allows you to insert a tag after the tag you have right-clicked on (skipping over any nested tags within the tag you have clicked on).Insert Tag Around allows you to insert a tag that will surround the originally selected tag..Insert Tag Inside this will insert a new tag nested within the initial tag you clicked on.Change Tag this allows you to change a tag (for example, turn a "lg" - line group - into a "p" - paragraph).Edit Tag this allows you to edit a tag by modifying the attributes of the tag.Copy Tag and Contents allows you to copy the tag and all the content (text) it contains. Remove Tag Only allows you to remove a tag, but keep the content (text, nested tags, etc.)Remove Content Only allows you to remove the content of a tag (text, nested tags, etc.), but keep the tag.Remove Tag and All Content allows you to remove everything within a tag and the tag itself.

section.title: Right-click menu in the entities column
section.p: You can edit entities by right-clicking on an entity in the entities panel on the left side of the editor.

p.lines: Edit Entity allows you to edit the qualifying information of an entity. This will bring up a pop-up where you can change the settings.
Remove Entity allows you to remove an entity, this will also remove the text that is tagged.
Copy Entity allows you to copy an entity and identifying information. to paste the entity, place your cursor in the text in the editor and right-click (choose to paste the entity).

section.title: Right-click menu in the relations column
section.p: The relations panel displays the relationships you've added between entities. To remove the entities, right-click on the relationship you would like to delete and choose the only option - Remove Relations.

reference.title: Saving CWRC-writer documents
reference.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer provides two options to save your changes and document. The first is a general save action, but the second allows users to save and then exit the document.

section.title: Saving your document
section.p: While you are working with your document periodically save any changes you have made by clicking on the “Save” icon in the toolbar. This will validate your document and save the changes that you have made.

section.title: Saving and exiting your document
section.p: If you are done working with your document we suggest the “Save and Exit” icon in the toolbar. This will do as the name suggests, save any changes you have made and then quit you out of CWRC-Writer, freeing it up for other users to edit or annotate the changes you have made.

reference.title: Copying and pasting
reference.shortdesc: Copying and pasting is the easiest way to build the structure of your document.

section.title: Introduction to copying and pasting
section.p: You can copy and paste in multiple ways in CWRC-Writer, this includes tags, text, and entities. There are multiple methods to copy and paste using your mouse's right-click button.

link.desc: Copying and pasting text into CWRC-Writer, can be achieved in two ways. The first, by highlighting text in the text area.

link.linktext: Copying and pasting a single tag
link.desc: Copying and pasting a tag allow you to duplicate structure and/or content with minimal effort. This acts as a type of shortcut tor producing content in you document.

Copying and pasting multiple tags within CWRC-Writer is the fastest way to build up a document. Whether you are adding poem lines or more notes, you can create entire sections of structure in a few easy steps.

link.linktext: Copying and pasting text in the structure panel
link.desc: This is how users can copy and paste text into CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag in the structure panel.

link.linktext: Viewing information copied from the structure panel
link.desc: CWRC-Writer provides the option of looking at what you have copied in the structure panel before you need to paste it in. This allows you to make sure you have selected exactly what you wanted to work with.

link.linktext: Copying and pasting entities in the editor
link.desc: You can copy and paste entities in CWRC-Writer. This will let you replicate annotations entities, so that you can have multiple instances of that tag in the document (with the same contextual information).

task.title: Copying and pasting text
task.shortdesc: Copying and pasting text into CWRC-Writer, can be achieved in two ways. The first, by highlighting text in the text area.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Copy the information that you would like to paste into CWRC-Writer.
step.info: You can copy any information from inside or outside of CWRC-Writer. If you copy text from another XML document all existing tags will be stripped out when the text is pasted into CWRC-Writer. CWRC-Writer only allows users to copy and paste using their keyboard shortcuts (Command C and V for Mac; Control C and V for P. C.s) and right-click menus.

step.cmd: Activate the field you are pasting into.
step.info: To do this, highlight the text you wish to paste over within the document in the editing pane. Currently you cannot paste into multiple tags at once. For example, in the prose document you need to paste in paragraphs one "p" tag at a time (this is true for lines, notes, etc. as well).

step.cmd: Paste text in, using the keyboard shortcuts, Cmd V or Ctrl V
step.stepresult: The text will show up in to the desired field. The structure panel tags will not be affected, unless you have pasted over preexisting tags. If you do those tags will be deleted.

link.linktext: Viewing information copied from the structure panel
link.desc: CWRC-Writer provides the option of looking at what you have copied in the structure panel before you need to paste it in. This allows you to make sure you have selected exactly what you wanted to work with.

link.linktext: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer with your cursor
link.desc: There are multiple ways to begin writing text in CWRC-Writer. You can select a tag and then begin to write, or you can place your cursor in the editor and begin to type.

link.linktext: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag
link.desc: There are multiple ways to begin writing text in CWRC-Writer. You can select a tag and then begin to write, or you can place your cursor in the editor and begin to type.

link.linktext: Deleting text from the structure panel
link.desc: CWRC-Writer templates open with pre-existing text. It may be easier to first delete the text (but not the tags) before adding your own text to the document.
You can add tags within the editor by highlighting the text and right-clicking. This will bring up a list of option available to you (adding entities, structural tags, editing, etc).

task.title: Copying and pasting a single tag
task.shortdesc: Copying and pasting a tag allow you to duplicate structure and/or content with minimal effort. This acts as a type of shortcut tor producing content in you document.

context.p: You can copy any single tag of your document, and paste it where ever you need to replicate that tag and/or information that tag contains.

step.cmd: To copy and paste one tag (and its content in the document) click on the tag (until the tag is bolded but not italicized) and use the keyboard shortcut to copy (Ctrl C / Cmd C).
Then select another tag or insert (using the right click menu) a tag in the structure panel, bolding the tag.
Then use Ctrl V or Cmd V to paste the single tag in.

link.desc: Copying and pasting multiple tags within CWRC-Writer is the fastest way to build up a document. Whether you are adding poem lines or more notes, you can create entire sections of structure in a few easy steps.

link.linktext: Copying and pasting text in the structure panel
link.desc: This is how users can copy and paste text into CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag in the structure panel.

link.linktext: Copying and pasting entities in the editor
link.desc: You can copy and paste entities in CWRC-Writer. This will let you replicate annotations entities, so that you can have multiple instances of that tag in the document (with the same contextual information).
You can add tags within the editor by highlighting the text and right-clicking. This will bring up a list of option available to you (adding entities, structural tags, editing, etc).
There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.

taskbody.context: You can copy any tag that exists in the document and the tags that are nested below it.

step.cmd: To copy and paste a parent tag and all the tags nested within it, the user needs to click twice on a tag (until it is bolded and italicized) and use your keyboard shortcut to copy.

info.note: CWRC-Writer only allows users to copy and paste using their keyboard shortcuts (Command C and V for Macs; Control C and V for P. C.s) and the right-click menu.

step.cmd: Right-click on a tag in the structure panel and choose one of the Insert Options. Depending on which option you chose this will insert a tag, before, after, or inside the tag you have selected.
step.info: To paste the tags in the document, we suggest first inserting a new tag into which you can paste.

step.cmd: Select the tag you have just added to the document until it is bolded and italicized. Use your keyboard shortcut to paste.

taskbody.result:
In the poem document you can click on a "lg" tag (until it is bolded and italicized) and use your keyboard shortcut (Command or Control C) to copy that tag.
Then insert a new "lg" tag by bolding the last one in the list and choosing the right-click option Insert Tag After (in this case choosing to insert a new "lg" tag).
When you choose to add a "lg" tag, this will create an empty tag that you can then paste the structure into; click on the tag (until it is bolded) and paste the information in. Success! You have pasted tags and text in the structure, creating a new "lg" tag with nested "l" tags.

reference.title: Tagging XML
reference.shortdesc: The CWRC-Writer allows editors of documents to mark up or embed semantic tags in documents using Extensible Markup Language (XML).

refbody.section:
Introduction to tagging XMLCWRC-Writer uses both the terms markup and tag to describe the embedding of XML (Extensible Markup Language) tags within the text of a document according to a predefined structure or schema. (For a gentel introduction to XML see http://www.w3schools.com/xml/). The markup or encoding makes the tagged features of the document available for search, analysis, and formatting while also ensuring that the text remains in a readily preservable format.
Document templates and sample documents contain some basic tags. The exisiting markup in your active document can be seen in the Markup panel. For more information see Navigation panelsThere are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.. You can add text to or delete it from the pre-existing tags, change the tags, and/or you can add new tags. For example, in the poetry template there are "lg" and "l" tags, into which you can type or copy text.

link.linktext: Adding structural tags by selecting text
link.desc: In each document that you work with there is a pre-existing XML template that contains the basic tags necessary for that type of document. You can add new structural tags to the document easily.

link.linktext: Adding structural tags in the structural panel
link.desc: In each document that you enter there is a pre-existing XML template that contains the basic tags necessary for that type document. You can add new structural tags to the document easily.
The document template that you are working with may have existing tags that you do not need for your document. You can easily delete these tags following these steps.

link.linktext: Deleting tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
link.desc: The document template that you are working with may have existing tags that you do not need for your document. You can easily delete these tags following these steps.
You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add contextual information to the tags in your document .

link.linktext: Editing tags in the structure panel
link.desc: You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add contextual information through attributes.

link.linktext: Editing tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
link.desc: You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add additional information to the tags in your document (E.g. next, rend, etc.).

step.cmd: Select text that you would like to add a structural tag to.
step.info: To insert a tag, you must first select the tag alone, and not the contents, by right/ctrl/command clicking twice.

step.cmd: Choose a tag from the toolbar drop down menu and select it.
Once you select the tag you would like to add to the structure panel, a pop-up will appear. This allows you to add qualifying information to the tag. Once you have finished, click on OK.
step.info: You do not have to enter any additional information you do not want to. You can just press OK as soon as you see this pop-up.
step.stepresult: You have now added a new structure tag. For example, in the image below you can see we have added a new "time" tag in the document structure, by following the above steps.

step.cmd: Select a tag in the structural panel and right click. To insert a tag, you must first select the tag alone, and not the contents, by right/ctrl/command clicking twice.
step.info: In the Markup panel, a single click right click (or control click on a Mac) selects both the tag and the contents. Deleting will delete both. A double click selects the content of the tag only. Deleting deletes the text only and more text can then be typed to replace it.

step.cmd: This will bring up a menu with three options that allow you to insert a tag.

choices.choice: Insert Tag Before allows you to insert a tag before the tag you have right clicked on.
Insert Tag After allows you to insert a tag after the tag you have right-clicked on (skipping over any nested tags within the tag you have clicked on).
Insert Tag Inside this will insert a new tag nested within the initial tag you clicked on.
Insert Tag Around will insert a tag surrounding the selected tag.

step.cmd: Once you have selected one of the Insert options, choose a tag from the list that appears.
step.info: The tags that you can select, under each Insert option, are limited to tags that are allowed (according to the schema).

step.cmd: Once you select the tag you would like to add to the structure panel a pop-up appear that allows you to add qualifying information to the tag. Once you have finished, click on OK.
step.info: You do not have to enter any additional information if you don't want to. You can just press OK as soon as you see this pop-up.

taskbody.result: You have now added a new structure tag. In the image below you can see we have added a new "time" tag in the document structure, by following the above steps.

reference.title: Tagging RDF entities
reference.shortdesc: Tagging RDF annotated entities in CWRC-Writer allows users to add semantic information to certain text (person, place, etc).

section.title: Introduction to tagging entities
section.p: You can add annotated entities to Person, Place, Date, Organization, Event, Citation, Note, Text/Title, Correction, Keyword, and Link. You can add qualifying information to the entities like the attributes precision and identification.

link.desc: CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from within the editor using your mouse right-click button. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.

CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from the toolbar using icon buttons. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.
The "Tag Person" option is for tagging people by name. It usually contains a proper noun or noun phrase, but can also contain pronouns or other ways of referring to someone.
Tag place is for tagging a place. It can describe both a geological location or a setting.
The "Tag Date" is for tagging a date in the text. This tag can contain the year, month, day or a combination of the three.
The "Tag Organization" entity is used to tag an organization or company.
The "Tag Text/Title" entity is for tagging a title or the text of any type of work
The "Tag Link" entity is for tagging any links or URL found in the document.
The "Tag Keyword" entity is tagging any important keywords in your document.
The "Tag Correction" entity is used to tag any correction you have made to the original text.
Notes must be applied to a span of text. They cannot be inserted into the text without the cursor having selected something, although they will be in the future.
Tag citation is for tagging citations in the text, which may contain a loosely structured bibliographic citation of which the subcomponents may or may not be explicitly tagged.

The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entity annotations as examples to new users. You can easily delete these annotations or any annotations that you don't want in your document from within the editor (using right-click).

link.linktext: Deleting entities from the entities column
link.desc: The CWRC-Writer templates comes with pre existing annotated entities as examples to new users. You can easily delete these entities, any entities that you don't want in you document, or those you have mistakenly added from the entities panel.

The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entity annotations as example to new users. You can easily delete these annotations or any annotations that you don't want in your document from the toolbar.
You can add qualifying information to the RDF entity annotations added to the document. This information can be edited at any time.

link.linktext: Editing entities from the entities column
link.desc: You can add qualifying information to the RDF entity annotations within the document. You can edit the entity annotations in the entity column on the left side of the editor. This information can be edited at any time.
You can add qualifying information to the RDF entity annotations in the document. You can edit the annotations from the toolbar at any time.

You can add relationships between the tagged entities within the document. You connect these entities with predicates, pre existing ones occur or you can add your own. This lets you create a semantic web of information within your document.
If you have mistakenly added a relation, you can delete them in the left column.

task.title: Tagging entities from the toolbar
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from the toolbar using icon buttons. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Commercialisation 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a particular entity.
step.info: Currently, the events tag is not fully functional.

step.cmd: Click on the entity toolbar button that you are adding to the document. In this case we are adding a "Person" tag to the sample letter document.
Choose CWRC, VIAF, GeoNames (depending on what entity you are tagging) entry and click on Select.
step.info: The editor is now hooked up to the CWRC entity system. Lookup of all named entities (e.g. persons, organizations, places, and titles) from within CWRC is now available, as well as lookup in authoritative linked data sources. The external VIAF list of authorities, produced from national and major research libraries around the world, is used to link persons, organizations and titles, while GeoNames is employed in a similar capacity for place entities.You can also create a new entry in the CWRC system, this will be covered in alternate help pages.

step.cmd: Add any qualifying information to the entity (Precision, identification, etc.) and click Save.
step.info: The option that show up on this pop-up depends on what entity is being tagged.

taskbody.result: The entity that you have added to your document (along with any additional information you have assigned to the entity) will appear in the entities column on the left side of the CWRC-Writer.

link.desc: CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from within the editor using your mouse right-click button. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.
The "Tag Person" option is for tagging people by name. It usually contains a proper noun or noun phrase, but can also contain pronouns or other ways of referring to someone.
Tag place is for tagging a place. It can describe both a geological location or a setting.
The "Tag Date" is for tagging a date in the text. This tag can contain the year, month, day or a combination of the three.
The "Tag Organization" entity is used to tag an organization or company.
The "Tag Text/Title" entity is for tagging a title or the text of any type of work
The "Tag Link" entity is for tagging any links or URL found in the document.
The "Tag Keyword" entity is tagging any important keywords in your document.
The "Tag Correction" entity is used to tag any correction you have made to the original text.
Notes must be applied to a span of text. They cannot be inserted into the text without the cursor having selected something, although they will be in the future.
Tag citation is for tagging citations in the text, which may contain a loosely structured bibliographic citation of which the subcomponents may or may not be explicitly tagged.
At the top of the editor there is a toolbar that allows you to add, edit, and delete tags and entities.
There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.
The editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.

task.title: Creating a new person entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Person" option is for tagging people by name. It usually contains a proper noun or noun phrase, but can also contain pronouns or other ways of referring to someone.

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a Person. Click on the toolbar or right-click options (see images below).
Try to find the person you are tagging in the CWRC or VIAF.
If your entry is not in the CWRC entity lookup system you have the option to create your own. To do this click on "Create New Person" button at the bottom of that page.
An "Add Person" pop-up appears, fill it out (see note) and click OK.
step.info: The only mandatory field is the "Person Name," though there are many other areas that you can fill out.

step.cmd: Once you have created a person entry in the CWRC entity repository, you can now add more information about the tag (precision, person type, etc.). Click on Save.

taskbody.result: You have now created a new CWRC entity entry, you can use this creation the next time that you go to tag this person.

task.title: Creating citation entities
task.shortdesc: Tag citation is for tagging citations in the text, which may contain a loosely structured bibliographic citation of which the subcomponents may or may not be explicitly tagged.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to add a citation to and right-click or use the toolbar icon.
A pop-up will appear with a list of titles from the CWRC and VIAF entries. Choose an option and click on Select.
A mini-editor will pop-up, enter any information that you would like in the pop-up.
step.info: There is a specific way to add text within tags in the mini-editor. To do this, you click the tag twice in the structure/markup tree, so that its entry is italicized (this means the tag's content is selected). You can then start typing, which will add text content to that tag. When using the mini-editor you can add XML and RDF tags just like in the main editor. though the toolbar options are limited (e.g. you cannot choose to "save" or "validate" the citation). The structure and entity panels on the left mimic the structure panel in the editor and displays all the tags you added to the citation in the mini-editor.

step.cmd: Once you have entered the text into the editor, you can begin to tag the document. Adding structural tags and entities to the document.
If/When you decide to add entities to your citation, you will see a pop-up exactly like that in CWRC-Writer.
Once you have finished creating the citation, click Select.

taskbody.result:
You have now created a citation in your document. You can see in the image below that the note appears in the document, currently the note does not format correctly in CWRC-Writer.
The resulting citation looks like this:

At the top of the editor there is a toolbar that allows you to add, edit, and delete tags and entities.
There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.
The editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.

reference.title: Introduction to CWRC-Writer Concepts
reference.shortdesc: We have included overall concepts in our CWRC-Writer documentation as background information for the user. this includes information on XML, RDF, Named Entity Annotation, and Relations/Triples.

section.title: Introduction to CWRC-Writer
section.p: The Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC) is developing an in-browser text markup editor (CWRC-Writer) for use by collaborative scholarly editing projects.
Features of CWRC-Writer

ul.li:
Web based
removes need to buy, install, and configure editing software
based on TinyMCE, a JavaScript editor using jQuery to extend functionality
Close-to-WYSIWYG editing and enrichment of scholarly texts with meaningful visual representational of markup

Combines eXtensible Markup Language (XML) and Resource Description Framework (RDF).
XML markup support crucial for DH community
RDF increasingly in use in DH projects;supports standoff and overlapping annotation of named entities, notes, etc.
ability to combine TEI markup with RDF for named entities and annotations.
ability to export using "weavers" that recombine plain text, the XML, and the RDF (including TEI-compliant XML)

Flexible Design
can be dropped into existing web frameworks
works with external services for e.g. entity management and validation
documentation open-source (github) code allows adoption and modification.

concept.title: Extensible Markup Language (XML)
concept.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows users to markup their document with eXtensible Markup Language (XML). In this document, we provide an overall description of XML.

section.title: What is XML?
section.p: eXtensible Markup Language (XML) is a markup language similar to HTML and SGML. Created by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C), XML documents can be easily read by both humans and machines (over the web). It allows you to markup your document with elements and the attribute that follows a hierarchy of rules.

The rules can be set by both the structure of the document (depending on if it is a poem, prose, etc.) and the schema used in the document. You can create your own schemas for your document, allowing you to define your own rules and attributes of this markup. CWRC-Writer allows you to upload your own schema to work with.

As noted above, XML consists of elements and attributes. Elements are the structure tags, they allow users to markup the hierarchy of the document. Attributes ass supplemental information to the elements tagged in a document. For example, if you are tagging a person, you can add qualifying information to the tag, such as if that person is real or fictional and that persons occupation (if any).

CWRC-Writer allows users to add the elements using a tag drop down menu in the toolbar. When you add the XML elements to your document, in the preloaded TEI XML tag, you are also presented with a pop-up where you can add attributes specific to that tag. For the major tags in CWRC-Writer (person, place, date, organization, citation, note, title, correction, keyword, and link) they have their own toolbar icons. These toolbar buttons add an XML and the corresponding RDF tag to the document, yet this depend on what method of overlap you are in. Please see the RDF and Overlap concepts for more information.

ul.li: World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). (Last modified 2014). Extensible Markup Language (XML). Retrieved November 1, 2014, from http://www.w3.org/XML/
World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Schools. (n.d.). XML tutorial. Retrieved November 1, 2014, from http://www.w3schools.com/xml/
Walsh, Norman. (1998). O'Reilly: A technical introduction to XML. Retrieved November 1, 2014, from http://www.xml.com/pub/a/98/10/guide0.html
Birnbaum, D.J. (n.d.). What is XML and why should humanists care? An even gentler introduction to XML. Retrieved November 1, 2014, from http://dh.obdurodon.org/what-is-xml.xhtml

li.xref: Resource Description Framework (RDF)CWRC-Writer allows users to markup their document with Resource Description Framework (RDF). In this document, we provide an overall description of RDF.

CWRC Entity systemThe editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.
CWRC-Writer ToolbarAt the top of the editor there is a toolbar that allows you to add, edit, and delete tags and entities.
Tagging XMLThe CWRC-Writer allows editors of documents to mark up or embed semantic tags in documents using Extensible Markup Language (XML).
Settings menuThe "Settings" options allow you to change the settings of your document.
Showing tags in editorShow tags allows you to view all the XML tags in the document.

concept.title: Resource Description Framework (RDF)
concept.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows users to markup their document with Resource Description Framework (RDF). In this document, we provide an overall description of RDF.

section.title: What is RDF?
section.p: The Resource Description Framework (RDF) was developed under the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). It is used to detail resources on the web. RDF is suitable for CWRC-Writer because it is written in XML. XML allows RDF to be processed by web operation systems, because RDF is not human readable in its raw form.

The resources described by RDF can include people, places, object, and/or documents. RDF information added to the document can be published across the web. Another term for this is “Linked Data”, and the user can follow this information to other document and sources of information. This allows you to seamlessly integrate your documents with the semantic web.

In CWRC-Writer you can add RDF resources to person, place, date, organization, citation, note, title, correction, keyword, and link from the toolbar. When you select one of these options a pop-up appears and you can linked data to the entity annotation. You can do this by lookup of named entities from within CWRC, as well as lookup in authoritative linked data sources. The external VIAF list of authorities, produced from national and major research libraries around the world, is used to link persons, organizations and titles, while GeoNames is employed in a similar capacity for place entities. More such authoritative sources will be added in future.
RDF is useful for CWRC-Writer because it allows you to semantically add information between datasets. This allows users to travel through threads of information linked together by RDF.

ul.li: World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Semantic Web. (n.d.). Resource Description Framework (RDF). Retrieved November 1, 2014, from https://www.w3.org/RDF/
World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Schools. (n.d.). Introduction to RDF. Retrieved November 1, 2014, from http://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_rdf.asp

Tagging RDF entitiesTagging RDF annotated entities in CWRC-Writer allows users to add semantic information to certain text (person, place, etc).

Berners-Lee, T. (n.d.). Linked Data - Design Issues. Retrieved November 1, 2014, from http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/LinkedData.html

concept.title: Named Entity Annotation
concept.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows users to markup their document with Named Entity Annotations. In this document, we provide an overall description of it.

section.title: What are Named Entity Annotations?
section.p: From the DH Poster 2012

One of the issues flagged early on was that many CWRC partner projects wanted sophisticated annotations for names, places, titles, organization names, dates, citations, and events, as well as great freedom for personal annotations, including overlapping annotations. There is also a desire for interoperability across projects, the coordination of authority lists for these entities, and the ability to harvest some annotations.

The solution is to provide an editing tool that uses a custom in-memory javascript data structure, that can export structural markup that conforms to schemas such as the TEI and Orlando ones, along with Open Annotation Collaboration (OAC) RDF for deeper semantic annotation (using controlled authority lists and vocabulary) of references to people, places, events, organizations, bibliographic material, and dates. CWRC-Writer thus supports creation of structural XML and the RDF in a WYSIWYG environment (WYSIWYG in that the annotations are displayed in the editor as they might appear in the public interface). The formatting of the text within the editor relieves the user of the complexity of interacting directly with RDF formats and even with angle brackets, though both can be viewed on demand and edited by those comfortable with code. There is also provision for exporting enhanced text either as structural markup combined with representations of entities as (potentially overlapping) RDF or, for those who opt for hierarchical markup, entirely as nested tags.

ul.li: World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Semantic Web. (n.d.). Resource Description Framework (RDF). Retrieved November 1, 2014, from http://www.w3.org/RDF/

concept.title: RDF Triples
concept.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows users to markup their document with Triples. In this document we provide and overall description of RDF triples.

section.title: Relations/Triples
section.p: When using RDF, the metadata is encoded as a triples. They use Uniform Resource Identifiers (WRI) to identify the relationships between the links (this is the triple).

Components of a RDF Triple:
The Objectis the object or value of the RDF annotation.
The Subject identifies what the object is describing in the annotation.
The Predicate points to the section of data in the object that the RDF annotation is giving a value to.
