reference.title: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
reference.shortdesc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.

section.title: DToC overview
section.p: The homepage of DToC lets users enter URLs, text, or XML documents. DToC is optimized for XML documents. Users upload pre existing XML documents by selecting the gear icon in the top right corner and then following the steps described in the “Upload your XML document to DToC” (linked below).
Additionally, users can paste/type in a URL or non-XML text into the text box provided on the first page of DToC.
Once you have enter the text, the “Reveal” button moves you into the main page of DToC.
The Dynamic Tables of Contexts is divided into four columns.

The text area contains the text of the document you’ve uploaded or entered into DToC. If your document has multiple sections then only the first section is visible in the text area when DToC loads. Below the text, at the bottom of the column, is a “Next Chapter” button (and/or a “Previous Chapter depending on what section you are viewing) that allows users to navigate between different sections of a document or different components of a collection.

The document model contains multiple lines that represent paragraphs of your document and are divided into sections or chapters by white spaces. These lines can become highlighted if they contain an index term, tag, or stat from the left column. Additionally, you can click on one of the lines to move the text area to that section of the text.

The table of contents displays the multiple sections or chapters of your document in a list. You can move between sections or chapters by clicking on the different titles located in the Table of Contents. This will reload the text in the right column to the section or chapter you’ve selected.
The left column provides you with four options to explore your text.

ul.li: The “Index” column arranges the terms alphabetically and displays the frequency of different terms in your document. Your index has to follow a certain XML syntax, one may want to upload a document that already has an index or to add an index to your document, please read “Adding an index to your XML document” linked below.
The “Tags” column shows all the XML tags searchable in your document. By clicking on the tags in the list you can see where they are situated in the sections.

The “Stats” tab displays the word frequencies in your document. You can sort the stats list by heading, list order, and category. Additionally, if you want to view just a few of the terms you can create a favorite list.
The “Annotations” displays any annotations made in the text area. To use this function you must be logged in to the “AnnotateIt” tool (a popup prompt comes up when you open this tab).

section.p: The Table of Contents, “Index,” and “Tag” tabs are only available if you upload an XML document with a structure compatible with DToC. See “Upload your XML document to DToC” (linked below) for more information and one of the XML document templates to get started.

link.desc: The Table of Contents shows the section or chapter breakdown of your document. The ToC will expand to display the information selected from the left column.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.
DToC provides different features to share and save your document for future use.

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).

link.linktext: Navigating text in the table of contents
link.desc: The Table of Contents displays terms selected (from the left column) and lets users move through the text by clicking on them. This allows for in-depth exploration of terms without scrolling through large chunks of text.
The Document Model is a deconstructed version of your document. Each section of grey lines represents a different section/chapter/article within the document.

The text is separated into chapters, sections, or articles by the XML document. The text area loads individual sections, so the whole document will not appear unless there are no text divisions in the document.

link.linktext: Filtering index terms, tags, and stats
link.desc: The search feature narrows down terms automatically as you type, whether they have the specific combination of letters you are typing anywhere in the word (not just if the word starts with the letters you are typing).

The search box is autocomplete-enabled. If you don't use that function (e.g. you continue to type your word or phrase without selecting a term from the drop down list) your search may not work if it has a spelling error or extra space.

When you move between different tabs in the left column they will not be filtered by the Chapter you have selected in the previous column. However, when you return to the initial tab, the chapter filter will remain selected.
You can customize how you view word frequencies in DToC by different organizational headings and by how the words are displayed under those headings.

link.linktext: Viewing stats by chapters and collections

link.desc: You can add as many terms as you would like to your “Favorites” list, either all at once or a few at a time.
You can add context to your annotations using the "AnnotateIt" tool. For more information about signing up to “AnnotateIt” see “Login/Annotator Authentication.”
The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, those that are found in your XML document or not.

reference.title: Table of contents
reference.shortdesc: The Table of Contents shows the section or chapter breakdown of your document. The ToC will expand to display the information selected from the left column.

section.p: Each section is represented by an orange dot and the title(s) and author(s) specified in your XML document. By clicking on one of the sections or chapters you change what appears in the reading column to what you’ve selected.
If you paste plain text or type in an URL in the DToC homepage there will not be anything in the Table of Contents.
When you select an option from the “Index, Tab, Stats or Annotation” column the Table of Contents will display and link to the location of the term/tag /word.

You can search the “Table of Contents.” The search box is auto complete enabled, but partial matches are not recognized (you cannot just type in the first few letters of a word and press enter as that will not be recognized). Once a search is conducted, the different sections or chapters that contain the search term will expand and show where in the text they are located with brief excerpts. To search for a new term, delete your word in the “Word Search” box and type/select a new one or press the “Clear” button located at the top of the document model (to the right of the Table of Contents).

Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.
DToC provides different features to share and save your document for future use.

reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)
reference.title: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
reference.shortdesc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.

section.title: General Information
section.p: The four tabs operate similarly in DToC.

When you click on an index term/tag/stat/annotation, DToC displays their location in different ways. The “Table of Contents” expands to show you where it is in each chapter/section. The document model highlights each line that contains the term. And the text area highlights the paragraphs that contain the selected term.

You can highlight index, terms, and words at the same time to see patterns in your text, each are represented by a different colour.
Index terms are represented by the colour orange.
Tags are represented in blue.
Word frequency terms are represented in purple.
To reset any search or filter option you can select the “Clear” button located at the top of the document model or unselect the chapter/section filter.

You can search or filter within the tabs. If you want to see a search term in a specific section/chapter, or see the index terms that are only found in a specific section/chapter, you can choose to “Filter by Chapter.”

Clicking on the “Filter by Chapter” brings up a drop down menu with the available sections to choose from. Once you have selected the chapter/section you want to focus on the index terms will automatically narrowed down.
If you’ve selected to filter by chapter in another section of the left column (e.g. Tag or Stats), this choice will not be remembered when you move to a different tab.

section.title: Index Tab
section.p: If you have terms indexed in your XML document they appear in the left column, organized under the index tab. For instructions on how to add an index see the "Adding an index to your XML document" link below. If you use an URL or paste in text rather than uploading your own XML document, you will not have an index.

The index can contain subsections and indexed cross references to provide a robust keyword catalogue. The numbers located beside each of the terms refers to how many time that term shows up in the complete text.

refbody.section:
Tags Tab
The “Tags” tab displays any of the tags found in your XML document. If you use an URL or paste in text rather than uploading your own XML document, the “Tags” tab will be empty.
You can highlight index, terms, and words at the same time to see patterns in your text. The numbers next to the tags display how many times the tag is found in the document.
You can view specific tags in the other columns by selecting one from the list or searching for it in the filter search box at the top of the column. If you want to see only the tags that are found in a specific chapter/section then you can choose the “Filter by Chapter” option at the top right of the column.
You can curate and add tags to your document.
The “Curator” mode is found in the “Settings” menu under the mode drop down menu. This will organize the tags under two headings, “Tag/Path” and the “Label.”
At the bottom of the column there are three options to “Curate” the tags.
“Add” allows you to add new tags to the list.
“Remove Selected” allows you to delete any tags in the list.
“Show Selected” allows you to see in both the “Table of Contents” and the “Text Area” where the tags are located (if present).
Once you choose to “Add” a tag there are three options. You can choose from a drop down menu of tags that are found in the document but may not be in the list already.You can add a new XML tag and the label you would like to apply to it. For example, you can add the ‘quote’ tag to the “Tag/Path” column and then label it “quotation” to the “Label” column.
If you would like to add tags that are not found in XML you can add them as targets. For example, if you would like to add a religion tag you can add it as a target of the ‘ref’ tag. It would look like this.
ref[@target*='religion']
This will add new tags to the tag list and will be viewable in the “Tag” column.

section.title: Stats Tab
section.p: The “Stats” tab displays the word frequency of your document. You can organize how you view word frequency by different organizational headings, by chapter or by creating a list of your “favorites.”
The Stats information is available whenever you use DToC (it is not dependent on uploading your own XML document).

You can view word frequencies in the reader column. Check the “Freq. Info in Reader” option in the "Settings" menu and when you hover your cursor over a word in the reader column the frequency of said word appears in a popup.

The preloaded organization options include “Type,” “Count,” “Relation,” and “Trend.” You can add or remove these options by choosing the black arrow menu that appears when you hover over the headings. The options are: “Sort Ascending,” “Sort Descending,” "Columns," “Group By This Field,” and “Show in Groups.”

The black arrow is not to be confused by a smaller grey arrow that is right beside the selected heading name (this option allows you to change the order of presentation -- alphabetical descending or ascending-- bypassing the need to select those options from the dropdown menu). You can see this gray arrow in the image below beside the "Type" column heading.
To change the headings available select the “Columns” option in the drop down menu to produce a checklist that you can customize.

This drop down menu also lets you choose the order that the words appear and how the words are grouped. If you would like to group by a specific organizational heading (e.g. Count) then you must select the black arrow drop down menu beside that option.
To change back to the default options click on the “Reset” option located at the bottom of the column.
You can filter terms by chapter or the entire document. At the top left of the column choose either “Chapter Stats” (the default selection) or “Collection Stats.”

If you don’t want to scroll through the list of terms, there is a search option at the bottom of the “Stats” column. The search feature is auto complete enabled. You need to select one of these options to search the “Stats” list.

The Stats tab also allows you to personalize a word frequency list under “favorites.” Select the term that you would like to “favorite” and then click on the double arrow button (located at the bottom of the column). This opens up a menu with two heart icons -- one with a green plus circle and just a plain heart. Choose the heart with the plus sign.

This will add the term(s) selected to your “favorites” list. To view the list click on the plain heart. To remove any words from your “favorites” list click on the heart with a red minus icon. This third heart icon appears at the bottom of the column when you are in your “favorites” list.

section.title: Annotation Tab
section.p: The Annotation tab displays the annotations that you have made in the text area. To annotate the text you must sign in to the tool “AnnotateIt.” Available at http://annotateit.org.

Once you have signed in and bookmarked “AnnotateIt” in your browser bar activate it by clicking on it while your DToC document is open (for more information see “Login/Annotator Authentication” and “Commenting on text”).
To annotate text highlight a chunk using your cursor in the Text Area. A small button appears to the right of your cursor (See below).

Click on this button to produce the annotation popup. This popup contains these annotation options:
“Comments” allows you to add additional information to the section of text you have highlighted.
“Allow anyone to view this annotation” is a check mark option to let anyone view the annotation you’ve made. It is preselected as a default.
“Allow anyone to edit this annotation” is an additional check mark option that allows people you share your document with to edit the annotations (once signed in to “AnnotateIt”). It is not selected as a default.
“Add some tags here…” use this to add XML tags to the text that you have highlighted.
“Cancel”/”Save” These buttons allow you to “Save” the document or “Cancel” creating the annotation (this option will delete the any option that you have entered).
You can view your annotations in the annotation tab. If you would like to “Filter” your annotations, type your search term in the “Filter” box. The search box is autocomplete-enabled.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.
The Table of Contents shows the section or chapter breakdown of your document. The ToC will expand to display the information selected from the left column.
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.
DToC provides different features to share and save your document for future use.

link.linktext: Creating an XML document for the Dynamic Table of Contexts
link.desc: In the Dynamic Table of Contexts (DToC) users can upload their own XML text. These XML documents need to be specially formatted in order to fully take advantage of DToC.

link.linktext: Adding XML ids to your document manually
link.desc: DToC uses XML ids as index locators; every index item is associated with one or more paragraph (as opposed to pages in print indexes).

This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.

link.linktext: Adding an index to your XML document
link.desc: DToC is best configured for documents that have indexes.
Cross referencing allows you to draw connections between terms found in different sections or chapters of your document.

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).

link.desc: The Table of Contents displays terms selected (from the left column) and lets users move through the text by clicking on them. This allows for in-depth exploration of terms without scrolling through large chunks of text.
The Document Model is a deconstructed version of your document. Each section of grey lines represents a different section/chapter/article within the document.

The text is separated into chapters, sections, or articles by the XML document. The text area loads individual sections, so the whole document will not appear unless there are no text divisions in the document.

link.linktext: Filtering index terms, tags, and stats
link.desc: The search feature narrows down terms automatically as you type, whether they have the specific combination of letters you are typing anywhere in the word (not just if the word starts with the letters you are typing).

The search box is autocomplete-enabled. If you don't use that function (e.g. you continue to type your word or phrase without selecting a term from the drop down list) your search may not work if it has a spelling error or extra space.

When you move between different tabs in the left column they will not be filtered by the Chapter you have selected in the previous column. However, when you return to the initial tab, the chapter filter will remain selected.
You can customize how you view word frequencies in DToC by different organizational headings and by how the words are displayed under those headings.

link.linktext: Viewing stats by chapters and collections

link.desc: You can add as many terms as you would like to your “Favorites” list, either all at once or a few at a time.
You can add context to your annotations using the "AnnotateIt" tool. For more information about signing up to “AnnotateIt” see “Login/Annotator Authentication.”

reference.title: XML templates
reference.shortdesc: Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.

section.title: Simple XML Template
section.p: We have provided a simple XML document that contains two chapters/sections and a preliminary index. You can open it in any XML compatible application (e.g. oXygen, Textedit, Textwrangler, etc.).

We have commented out instructions within the XML document. For example, we have identified three different options available in the index -- indexing terms, subsection, and cross referencing index terms. Each method is found in this template.
This template is a valid XML document.

reference.title: Settings

section.p: “Settings” is located in the upper right corner of DToC and is represented by a small gear icon.

Setting Options:
Chapter Titles: Allow you to either view the “Full Titles” (default option) or as “Condensed Titles with Pop-up” in the Table of Contents.
Freq. Info in Reader: Allows users to choose to view the word frequency information in the text area. When you hover your cursor over a word in the reader column the frequency of said word appears in a small popup.
Mode: This changes how you view the Tags column. The two options are “Default” or “Curator.” The “Curator” option organizes tags by two headings “Label” and “Tag/Path” (see image below). The “Curator” option allows you to add your own tags to the document.
Export: The “Export” option is used to create and preserve a link to the curated version of your document (See Digital Publication linked below).

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).
The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, those that are found in your XML document or not.

reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)
reference.title: Digital publication options
reference.shortdesc: DToC provides different features to share and save your document for future use.

section.title: Export Document
section.p: DToC provides you with an URL to preserve a link of your curated document. The “Export” option is found under the settings menu option (upper right corner).

Once you have opened the settings menu choose the “Export” button. This opens another popup that contains the URL for your document. You can either click on the linked “URL” option, which opens a new browser window or copy and paste the URL.

section.title: XML Digital View
section.p: For XML documents only, you can click on the "XML" button located in the upper right corner. This will open a new browser window with a display of your document XML structure.
You can bookmark this page. If you try to print this version of your document, the XML structure will not be printed, just the text.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.
The Table of Contents shows the section or chapter breakdown of your document. The ToC will expand to display the information selected from the left column.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Navigating text in the table of contents
task.shortdesc: The Table of Contents displays terms selected (from the left column) and lets users move through the text by clicking on them. This allows for in-depth exploration of terms without scrolling through large chunks of text.

step.cmd: Click on a section/chapter/article in the Table of Contents.
step.info: This will move the black arrow of the document model to the text that you have selected.

step.cmd: Scroll to read.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.
The Table of Contents shows the section or chapter breakdown of your document. The ToC will expand to display the information selected from the left column.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).
The Document Model is a deconstructed version of your document. Each section of grey lines represents a different section/chapter/article within the document.

The text is separated into chapters, sections, or articles by the XML document. The text area loads individual sections, so the whole document will not appear unless there are no text divisions in the document.

link.linktext: Filtering index terms, tags, and stats
link.desc: The search feature narrows down terms automatically as you type, whether they have the specific combination of letters you are typing anywhere in the word (not just if the word starts with the letters you are typing).

The search box is autocomplete-enabled. If you don't use that function (e.g. you continue to type your word or phrase without selecting a term from the drop down list) your search may not work if it has a spelling error or extra space.

When you move between different tabs in the left column they will not be filtered by the Chapter you have selected in the previous column. However, when you return to the initial tab, the chapter filter will remain selected.
You can customize how you view word frequencies in DToC by different organizational headings and by how the words are displayed under those headings.

link.linktext: Viewing stats by chapters and collections

link.desc: You can add as many terms as you would like to your “Favorites” list, either all at once or a few at a time.
You can add context to your annotations using the "AnnotateIt" tool. For more information about signing up to “AnnotateIt” see “Login/Annotator Authentication.”
The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, those that are found in your XML document or not.

task.title: Navigating the document model
task.shortdesc: The Document Model is a deconstructed version of your document. Each section of grey lines represents a different section/chapter/article within the document.

step.cmd: Click on a section in the document model.
step.info: The table of contents and the title at the top of text column will tell you what section you've selected.

step.cmd: Work with the "Index," "Tags," and "Stats" columns and see what lines are highlighted.
When you are done working with the Document model or would like to start a new search, click on the "Clear" button at the top of the Document Model.

task.title: Navigating the text area
task.shortdesc: The text is separated into chapters, sections, or articles by the XML document. The text area loads individual sections, so the whole document will not appear unless there are no text divisions in the document.

step.cmd: Scroll to the bottom of the text in the text area.
Click on "Next Chapter" or "Previous Chapter" to navigate through the document sections.

task.title: Filtering index terms, tags, and stats
task.shortdesc: The search feature narrows down terms automatically as you type, whether they have the specific combination of letters you are typing anywhere in the word (not just if the word starts with the letters you are typing).

step.cmd: Type the term or tag that you would like to locate in the list. You can search for terms or tags found in a specific chapter by selecting an option from the “Filter by Chapter” drop down menu. The Stats column search filter is located at the bottom of the column.
step.info: You can search for terms or tags found in a specific chapter by selecting an option from the “Filter by Chapter” drop down menu. The Stats column search filter is located at the bottom of the column.

step.cmd: Type the term or tag that you would like to locate in the list. You can search for terms or tags found in a specific chapter by selecting an option from the “Filter by Chapter” drop down menu.
step.info: Terms are represented in orange, tags in blue, and words in purple.

step.cmd: To restart your search choose the “Clear” button located at the top of the document model.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.

link.linktext: Adding XML ids to your document manually
link.desc: DToC uses XML ids as index locators; every index item is associated with one or more paragraph (as opposed to pages in print indexes).

This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.

link.linktext: Adding an index to your XML document
link.desc: DToC is best configured for documents that have indexes.
Cross referencing allows you to draw connections between terms found in different sections or chapters of your document.

link.linktext: Navigating text in the table of contents
link.desc: The Table of Contents displays terms selected (from the left column) and lets users move through the text by clicking on them. This allows for in-depth exploration of terms without scrolling through large chunks of text.

When you move between different tabs in the left column they will not be filtered by the Chapter you have selected in the previous column. However, when you return to the initial tab, the chapter filter will remain selected.
You can customize how you view word frequencies in DToC by different organizational headings and by how the words are displayed under those headings.

task.title: Searching the full text
task.shortdesc: The search box is autocomplete-enabled. If you don't use that function (e.g. you continue to type your word or phrase without selecting a term from the drop down list) your search may not work if it has a spelling error or extra space.

context.p: If you have selected a chapter from the Table of Contents then your search will only be conducted within that chapter. If you would like to conduct a full text search make sure that none of the chapters/sections are selected.

step.cmd: Type in the word(s) that you are searching for.
DToC displays the location of the word you are looking for in the table of content and document model.
To restart your search choose the “Clear” button located at the top of the document model.

task.title: Filtering by chapter
task.shortdesc: When you move between different tabs in the left column they will not be filtered by the Chapter you have selected in the previous column. However, when you return to the initial tab, the chapter filter will remain selected.

step.cmd: Select the "Index" or "Tags" tab in the left column.
Choose the “Filter by Chapter” drop down menu. Select the chapter you would like a closer examination of. This will narrow down the index terms to those found in the selected chapter.
You can then select an index term or tag to see where they are located in the selected chapter.
To reset the filter, click again on the “Filter by Chapter” drop down menu and unselect the chapter you have selected. Or click on the "Clear" button above the document model.

task.title: Sorting word frequencies
task.shortdesc: You can customize how you view word frequencies in DToC by different organizational headings and by how the words are displayed under those headings.

step.cmd: Select the heading you would like to view the list of words organized by.
Select how you would like the word frequencies to be organized by choosing one of the options available from the drop down menu.

You can add more options by clicking on the black arrow menu option that appears beside the organization headings when you hover your mouse over it. This brings up a drop down menu, select the “Column” option that displays another drop down menu filled with additional heading options.

task.title: Viewing word frequencies

step.cmd: Click on the “Stats” tab on the left column.
Scroll through the list and check any words you would like to see the location of in the chapter or document.
To reset DToC hit the “Clear” button located above the black arrow text column.

task.title: Viewing stats by chapters and collections

step.cmd: Select an option to view the word frequencies. You can either choose to view words by individual chapters or by the entire document.
If you have selected to view words found in chapters or sections, you must then select the chapter you want from the table of contents. Click once on the chapter you want to work with.
step.info: When you enter the “Stats” tab or select the “Chapter Stats” option, the first chapter is the default view.

step.cmd: If you have selected to view the words by collection (which refers to the entire document with all chapters), continue to explore the listed words.

task.title: Favoriting words
task.shortdesc: You can add as many terms as you would like to your “Favorites” list, either all at once or a few at a time.

step.cmd: Select words you would like to favorite by checking the box beside them.
Click on the double black arrow icon located at the lower right corner of the “Stats” column.
Click on the red heart icon that has the green plus sign. This will add the selected terms to a “Favorites” list.
To switch back and forth from the original list to your “favorites,” click on the heart icon (that does not have any additional icons attached).
To remove a word from your “Favorites” list, select it and click on the heart that has a red minus icon. This icon is not located in the favorites drop down menu, but beside it.

task.title: Exporting your document

step.cmd: Click on the gear icon in the top right corner of the text column.
Select the “Export” button at the bottom of the popup.
A second popup appears with a URL for your document. Click on “URL” (highlighted in blue) to open your document in a new window.
Click on “OK”, you will now have two versions of your document open.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.
DToC provides different features to share and save your document for future use.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Logging in to the annotator

step.cmd: Click on the Annotation tab or “Export” button within the annotation tab to produce an “Annotator Authentication” popup.
Click on the “Annotator Login” button.
If you have an account, login, if you don't follow the instructions provided by “AnnotateIt.”
Once you have an account with “AnnotateIt” bookmark the site to your browser bookmark bar.
Reload your DToC document and click on the “AnnotateIt” bookmark on your bookmark bar.
Begin to annotate your document in the text area.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.
You can add context to your annotations using the "AnnotateIt" tool. For more information about signing up to “AnnotateIt” see “Login/Annotator Authentication.”
The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, those that are found in your XML document or not.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Annotating your text
task.shortdesc: You can add context to your annotations using the "AnnotateIt" tool. For more information about signing up to “AnnotateIt” see “Login/Annotator Authentication.”

step.cmd: Log in to “AnnotateIt” and activate it in your DToC browser (See “Login/Annotator Authentication” linked below).
Highlight the text you would like to comment on in the text area.
Click on the small popup that appears over your cursor (it is represented by a pen and page).
In the comment section, write any information that you would like to annotate the highlighted text with.
Select one of the View/Edit options (see image below).
step.info: You can check both options, so that they have the option either view or edit the annotations.

step.cmd: Enter any tags that you would like to add to your highlighted text.

Once you have finished adding the information to your text click on “Save.” If you don’t want to annotate the text or you have changed your mind you can click on “Cancel” and your annotation will not appear.
If you would like to delete or edit the annotation click on it and select one of those options in the top left corner of the popup.
step.info: If you delete the annotation you will delete everything, comment, view setting, and tag.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.
The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, those that are found in your XML document or not.

task.title: Curating tags
task.shortdesc: The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, those that are found in your XML document or not.

step.cmd: Click on the “Settings” menu in the top right corner.
Select the “Curator” option under the “Mode” drop down menu. Click "OK."
Select the “Add” button option at the bottom of the column.

Enter in the XML tag in the right drop down menu and the label you would like to see accompany it. For example, in the “Tag/Path” column you would put ‘quote’ and in the left column put in ‘quote’ or ‘quotation.’
step.info: For more information about adding different types of tags see the "Left Column of Dynamic Table of Context" reference document.

step.cmd: If you would like to delete a tag or view where the tags are located in the “Table of Contents” or “Text Area.” Select one of other two options at the bottom of the page.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.

link.linktext: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: This column allow users to search and browse the document by key terms, tags, and word frequency information.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating an XML document for the Dynamic Table of Contexts
task.shortdesc: In the Dynamic Table of Contexts (DToC) users can upload their own XML text. These XML documents need to be specially formatted in order to fully take advantage of DToC.

context.p: If you would like to follow along with these instructions you can download a template here: http://cwrc.ca/templates/DToC_Document_Template.xml
You can open this template in oXygen, TextEdit, TextWrangler, etc.

step.cmd: Open an application that allows you to create an XML document (oXygen, TextWrangler, Textedit, etc.). Our documentation here uses the Oxygen XML editor http://www.oxygenxml.com/
Enter the XML declaration and TEI P5 schema definition
Add informations to your TEI header.
step.info: The TEI Header helps you to define the title, publication information, and source information about the document you are working on.

step.cmd: In the body section of your document, wrap div tags around each of your chapters (or sections that you want to be separately itemized within the table of contents). These <div> tags should include a ‘type’ attribute with the value of ‘chapter’ <div type='chapter'>
step.info: You define the div tags into chapters so that the different chapters will appear in the Table of Contents feature in the DToC (see images below). This is optional, if you don’t have multiple chapters you don't need this option. However, if you do and do not include this ‘type’ attribute then the chapters will blur together into one section of text. All the div tags in the template are predefined with "type='chapter'.

step.cmd: At the top of each chapter div, add the chapter’s author and title information (see image above).
step.info: We have used TEI’s "head" tag to distinguish the headers from the body text; we have also wrapped it in a bibliographic element. This ensures that any information in a ‘head’ tag will appear in the Table of Content and at the top of the text column depending on what chapter is being examined.

step.cmd: Begin marking up your document. Here is an example of a simple XML document that DToC will accept.
step.info: This document only has one chapter associated with it and no index. If you would like to add additional chapters, see below. For more information about adding an index see the “Adding an index” linked below.

step.cmd: If you would like to add additional chapters, copy the tags and text between and including the <div> tags and paste that information below the last <div> tag. Then begin to fill in the information for your next chapter.
You can now continue to mark up your text with XML tags (e.g. event, place, organization, etc.). These tags will appear in the Tags column on the left side of the DToC tool.

link.linktext: Adding XML ids to your document manually
link.desc: DToC uses XML ids as index locators; every index item is associated with one or more paragraph (as opposed to pages in print indexes).

This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.

link.linktext: Adding an index to your XML document
link.desc: DToC is best configured for documents that have indexes.
Cross referencing allows you to draw connections between terms found in different sections or chapters of your document.

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Adding XML ids to your document manually
task.shortdesc: DToC uses XML ids as index locators; every index item is associated with one or more paragraph (as opposed to pages in print indexes).

context.p: If your document is small you can add your own XML ids. If you have a larger document, we suggest that you open your document in Oxygen where you can add XML ids quickly and easily (see the document "Adding XML ids with oXygen").

step.cmd: Add a XML id within your 'p' tags in your document. To do this insert your cursor between the ‘p’ text and the right angle bracket and add an xml:id='' attribute.
step.info: It is optional to assign XML ids located in the TEI Header.

step.cmd: Assign values to your XML ids.
step.info: Your ids can be a letter or numerical value, but you must differentiate between the different tags.

step.cmd: Finish adding XML ids to all your 'p' tags.
step.info: You can add XML ids to any type of tag. For example, if you would like to index any citations in your document you can add XML ids to the 'note' tags. Alternatively, if you would like to cross reference your index you can also add XML ids to the 'item' tags. For more information please refer to the document "Creating Cross Referencing Index terms" linked to below.

example.p: Open the XML document, “A Scandal in Bohemia: Chapter 1”.
For each paragraph within the body of text add an unique identifier. For example, you can use “P” and then the number of what paragraph it is. So the fifth paragraph would be “P5”.

You can use a combination of letters and numbers, but you cannot have spaces located within the XML id attribute. You can use underscores. Each paragraph, even if they are in different chapters needs a distinct id.

link.linktext: Creating an XML document for the Dynamic Table of Contexts
link.desc: In the Dynamic Table of Contexts (DToC) users can upload their own XML text. These XML documents need to be specially formatted in order to fully take advantage of DToC.

This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.
Cross referencing allows you to draw connections between terms found in different sections or chapters of your document.

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.

task.title: Adding XML ids with oXygen
task.shortdesc: This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.

step.cmd: Open your XML document in oXygen.
Switch to author mode, either at the bottom of your document or under the “Author” tab in the main menu.
Under the “TEI P5” tab in the main menu select “ID Options."
In the popup menu add the XML tags that you would like to generate XML ids for. In this case 'div' is pre typed in but you can add 'p' to that list and delete the 'div' option. Click ‘OK’.
step.info: This tutorial focuses on the 'p' tags, however you can add XML ids to many other tags (e.g. note, list, etc). For example, if you would like to be more specific in where the index terms are located you can go through the optional step of adding keyword tags to specific index terms within paragraphs. Then add the 'keyword' tag to the list in the “ID Options.” If you would like to cross reference your index terms then you need to add XML ids to the ‘item’ tag.

step.cmd: Select the entire content in the author page and click on ‘Generate IDs,’ located under the main menu “TEI P5” option. This will generate XML ids for all the selected tags from step 4.
Save your document.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Adding an index to your XML document
task.shortdesc: DToC is best configured for documents that have indexes.

step.cmd: Open up your XML document.
Open up a new div at the end of your XML file; add a ‘type’ attribute called ‘index’.
Under the <div> tag add a <list> tag.
step.info: DToC expects the index to have a particular structure: list > item > ref. Essentially, what you are creating is an indexed list; the TEI tags mentioned above allow you to structure the list’s hierarchy.

step.cmd: Within the <list> tag add the <item> tag. Each <item> tag wraps around each index entry (it’s content is the index term).
Add a <ref> tag to the items in the list.
step.info: The <ref> tag has a target attribute, whose value is a space separated list of paragraph XML IDs. The <ref> tag references the paragraph in the body text.

step.cmd: Begin to add your index terms between the item/ref tags. The index contain terms for all the sections (or chapters) of your document.
step.info: The index can be simple or complex depending on your document and/or the effort that you put in to it. For example, the sections below detail how you can cross reference the index or add sub terms within an index theme.

step.cmd: Now note all the paragraph XML ids that the terms are found in. It may be helpful to write this down before you begin creating your index, or you can add the XML ids to your index as you go.
Add the XML ids (from the paragraph(s) or other tags) in the target attribute of the <ref> tag. If there are multiple XML ids related to the index term, separate these with a space.
Save your document.
step.info: Once you have uploaded your document to DToC it will look like this:

example.p: The index term “Sherlock” is located in four in the paragraphs of the document.

Record/Note the paragraphs that contain the index term. In this case, the index term is located in the third, fourth, fifth, and sixth paragraphs. These paragraphs are in a small document and have been assigned their own XML ids by the author/creator.
Within the ref tag add the “target” attribute. Then add the paragraph XML ids within the target quotation marks. If there are multiple paragraphs that contain this keyword separate them with a space.

task.title: Creating index subheadings

step.cmd: Nest a ‘list’ tag within an ‘item’ tag.
step.info: An example index:

step.cmd: Within the 'list' tag add an 'item' tag. So the breadcrumb trail would be item>lists>item(s). Each 'item' tag wraps around each index entry (it’s content is the index term).
Step 3: Add a <ref> tag to the items in the list.
step.info: The 'ref' tag has a target attribute, its value is a space separated list of paragraph XML IDs. The 'ref' tag references the paragraphs in the body text.

step.cmd: Begin to add your index terms between the item/ref tags.
Add the XML ids (from the paragraph(s) or other tags) in the target attribute of the <ref> tag. If there are multiple XML ids related to the index term, separate these with a space.

task.title: Creating cross referencing index terms
task.shortdesc: Cross referencing allows you to draw connections between terms found in different sections or chapters of your document.

step.cmd: Make sure you have XML ids attached to your ‘item’ tags in the index.
Below the ‘item’ ‘ref’ tags add a ‘list’ tag.
Add a ‘head’ tag below the newly created list tag.

Within the ‘head’ tag add a ‘hi’ tag. To the ‘hi’ tag add the ‘rend’ attribute, the value of the ‘rend’ will be “italic” (see below). Between the ‘hi’ tag add “See also” or something of that effect. Close out the ‘head’ tag after the ‘hi’ tag.
step.info: The 'hi' tag "Highlights" the "See also" term.

step.cmd: Now add the ‘item’ tag(s) to the list (below the closed of ‘head’ tag). The ‘ref’ tag target attribute will contain the XML id or ids that of different index terms that you would like to cross reference.
step.info: You can add as many items to this section as you would like.

step.cmd: Close out the list tag.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Uploading your XML document to DToC
task.shortdesc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

step.cmd: Open up the settings in the homepage of DToC. This option is represented by a gear in the top right corner of the “Add Text” box.
Change the “Input Format” to TEI.
Enter this XPath information into the corresponding areas (in the info section below).
step.info:
XPath to Content: *
XPath to Author: //*[local-name()='head']//*[local-name()='author']
XPath to Title: //*[local-name()='head']//*[local-name()='title']
XPath to Documents: //*[local-name()='div' and('chapter'=@*[local-name()='type'] or 'forward'=@*[local-name()='type'] or 'index'=@*[local-name()='type'])] DToC splits the XML into "documents" based on XPath criteria that is provided when importing the file into DToC. The "XPath to document" section assumes that your document is organized into chapter(s), a forward, and an index. You may have to configure the XPath to document section if your document has additional structure components (such as an afterword).
Each chapter should have author and title info. When importing, you can provide XPaths to these values, relative to the parent chapter.To add an after word, you would need to add this expression to the larger chain:
‘afterword’=@*[local-name()=’type’]
The XPath to Documents chain would now look like:
//*[local-name()='div' and('chapter'=@*[local-name()='type'] or 'forward'=@*[local-name()='type'] or ‘afterword’=@*[local-name()=’type’] or 'index'=@*[local-name()='type'])]
For more information on XPaths see http://www.w3schools.com/xsl/xpath_intro.asp

step.cmd: Click "OK".
Click on the “Upload” button in the lower right corner.
A popup appears. Click on the “Add” option at the top of the popup.
Select the XML document on your computer that you would like to upload to DToC.
step.info: If you accidentally uploaded the wrong document click on the left icon (the red delete symbol) and upload the correct document. Or you can upload more than one document, but only one with be “Revealed.”

step.cmd: Once the document appears in the upload popup, click on “Reveal.” Voyant will process your document. Once it is finished processing your document, DToC will open with your XML document uploaded.

link.linktext: Creating an XML document for the Dynamic Table of Contexts
link.desc: In the Dynamic Table of Contexts (DToC) users can upload their own XML text. These XML documents need to be specially formatted in order to fully take advantage of DToC.

link.linktext: Adding XML ids to your document manually
link.desc: DToC uses XML ids as index locators; every index item is associated with one or more paragraph (as opposed to pages in print indexes).

This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.

link.linktext: Adding an index to your XML document
link.desc: DToC is best configured for documents that have indexes.
Cross referencing allows you to draw connections between terms found in different sections or chapters of your document.

link.linktext: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
link.desc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.

task.title: Uploading text and URLs into DToC
task.shortdesc: Some features will be unavailable using this method (like the index).

step.cmd: Paste your text or an URL into the text box located on the front page of DToC.
Click on the “Reveal” button located right below the text box. This opens the document in DToC.
Begin to work with your text.
step.info: Using this method, you will not have an index, tags or search functionality (even if you paste in an XML document). The table of contents and the document model will also not work. However, you will be able to see information in the stats column (term frequency).
This image displays the simple XML template uploaded using the copy and paste text box (with tags) instead of the XPath method.

link.linktext: Creating an XML document for the Dynamic Table of Contexts
link.desc: In the Dynamic Table of Contexts (DToC) users can upload their own XML text. These XML documents need to be specially formatted in order to fully take advantage of DToC.

link.linktext: Adding XML ids to your document manually
link.desc: DToC uses XML ids as index locators; every index item is associated with one or more paragraph (as opposed to pages in print indexes).

This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.

link.linktext: Adding an index to your XML document
link.desc: DToC is best configured for documents that have indexes.
Cross referencing allows you to draw connections between terms found in different sections or chapters of your document.

link.linktext: Uploading your XML document to DToC
link.desc: DToC requires XPath information to upload original XML documents. These may changes depending on how you have structured your document. The below information is for a XML document that follows the template structure, but we have noted how you can change the XPath information to match your document.

link.linktext: Overview of Dynamic Table of Context
link.desc: The Dynamic Table of Context (DToC) lets users reveal information about their text that is not necessarily discovered when reading, such as word frequencies. DToC also allows users to customize their document with annotations and adding tags.
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.

concept.title: What is HuViz?
concept.shortdesc: Humanities Visualizer (HuViz) is a browser-based tool for visualing linked data.

conbody.p: HuViz allows researchers to explore RDF datasets and ontologies in the form of an interactive graph. The user can discover connections between entities -- such as: people, places and organizations -- either by clicking and dragging nodes directly into the Graph or by executing commands in the Commands Tab.

The test datasets for the HuViz prototype are generated from the Orlando Project textbase. However, the tool is theoretically compatible with any RDF-styled data. In the future, we anticipiate expanding the capabilities of HuViz to allow researchers to process and refine their own datasets and author links from within the tool itself.

link.desc: The quickest and most intuitive way to manipulate the dataset is directly in the graph.
Working directly in the Graph using the "drag and drop" technique involves fewer steps. However, working from the Commands Tab has multiple benefits.

concept.title: Using the Graph
concept.shortdesc: The quickest and most intuitive way to manipulate the dataset is directly in the graph.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

conbody.p: Almost all actions can be performed on the nodes either through a single click or a "drag and drop."
conbody.note: The exception is Label and Hide, which can only be performed in the Commands Tab.

p.note: Nodes can be dragged between any of the three main areas: central Graph, Shelf and Discard Bin.

link.desc: Working directly in the Graph using the "drag and drop" technique involves fewer steps. However, working from the Commands Tab has multiple benefits.
Graph nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
Shelve nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
Discard nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.

concept.title: Using the Commands Tab
concept.shortdesc: Working directly in the Graph using the "drag and drop" technique involves fewer steps. However, working from the Commands Tab has multiple benefits.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

ul.li: Certain commands, like Label and Hide, cannot be executed manually. The Commands Tab gives users access to the full range of tools.

Users also have more control over how those tools are implemented. For example, when Working manually, only a single node or node cluster can be manipulated at a given time. In the Commands Tab, users have the option to filter nodes by type.

link.desc: The quickest and most intuitive way to manipulate the dataset is directly in the graph.
The Current Command box acts as a prompt to notify the user which elements need to be selected to execute a command.
In the Commands Tab, actions are automatically executed when a selected Set or Class type is combined with a Verb.

concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)
concept.title: Current Command
concept.shortdesc: The Current Command box acts as a prompt to notify the user which elements need to be selected to execute a command.

conbody.p: The elements of a command are represented by the formula: Verb + Set/Class. This formula is displayed in the Current Command box, located near the top of the Commands Tab. The Current Command box automatically updates when the user selects these elements from the Verb + Set/Class boxes.
If an element has not been Selected, it will display the greyed out formula Verb + Set/Class to indicate these elments are empty and prompt the user to choose them.
The Verb element and Set/Class element can be entered in any order - it does not matter which element is picked first - but both need to be present for the action to take place.
conbody.example: "Label" + Set/Class indicates that the Verb label has been selected. Set/Class is blank indicating that the user needs to choose this elements to execute the command.

link.desc: Working directly in the Graph using the "drag and drop" technique involves fewer steps. However, working from the Commands Tab has multiple benefits.
In the Commands Tab, actions are automatically executed when a selected Set or Class type is combined with a Verb.

task.title: Load a Dataset
task.shortdesc: To begin, choose a dataset.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

context.p: In the HuViz prototype, the pre-loaded datasets are generated from the Orlando textbase and organized by theme.

step.cmd: Click the Commands tab to open the main control panel.
At the top of the panel, click the drop down menu labelled "Pick a Dataset."
Hover over specific datasets to view a list of attributes.
step.info: The number of nodes, edges and predicates are a general indication of the size and complexity of the network.

step.cmd: Click on the dataset to load.
step.info: The size of a dataset (i.e. number of nodes and predicates it contains) will effect the loading time.

taskbody.result: Once the data has finished parsing, the process is complete. The dataset has sucessfully loaded and nodes are in orbit, ready for action.

concept.title: Select
concept.shortdesc: Use the Select function to choose which nodes to execute a command on.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

conbody.p:
There are three ways of Selecting nodes: Methods of Selecting Nodes
Workspace Method
Graph
Manually, using the "drag and drop" technique
Commands Tab
By Set or Class type
Using the Like (search) function
Once nodes have been selected, future actions will be performed only on those nodes and can be executed by clicking a Verb or sequence of Verbs.

link.desc: It is easy to tell the difference between Selected from Unselected nodes.
The All function is used to perform actions on all nodes at the same time.
Select nodes by hand with the following steps.
Select nodes by Set or Class using the Commands Tab.
Select nodes using the Like bar to perform a text search.
Working directly in the Graph using the "drag and drop" technique involves fewer steps. However, working from the Commands Tab has multiple benefits.
In the Commands Tab, actions are automatically executed when a selected Set or Class type is combined with a Verb.

Click node once to Select.

ul.li: Click node a second time to Unselect. The node's appearance will change back to normal, indicating that is in a Unselected state.

task.title: Select All
task.shortdesc: The All function is used to perform actions on all nodes at the same time.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

context.p: When using the select All function, executing a Verb will effect all nodes in the orginal dataset. This includes nodes that are Hidden or Discarded. As such, the All function can be used to recall nodes that have been rendered temporarily invisible and cannot be dragged by into the graph manually.

step.cmd: Click All, located at the top of the Sets bar.
step.info: The Sets bar will highlight in full, indicating that all nodes will be affected. Under Current Command, the "Sets/Classes" element will change to "All."

step.cmd: Click on the desired Verb to execute the action.

link.desc: Use the Select function to choose which nodes to execute a command on.
Select nodes by hand with the following steps.
Select nodes by Set or Class using the Commands Tab.
Select nodes using the Like bar to perform a text search.
Working directly in the Graph using the "drag and drop" technique involves fewer steps. However, working from the Commands Tab has multiple benefits.
In the Commands Tab, actions are automatically executed when a selected Set or Class type is combined with a Verb.

task.title: Select by Set or Class
task.shortdesc: Select nodes by Set or Class using the Commands Tab.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the individual drawer of the desired Set or Class type to select contents.
Click on a Verb to execute action.

ul.li: Actions can be performed on multiple Set or Class types. Select as many drawers as needed before executing the action by clicking a Verb.

taskbody.result:
The drawer will turn a darker shade and the name of the Set or Class type will appear under the Current Command.
If a Class type was selected, the Edge types associated with that Class will appear as drawers in the Edges of Selected Nodes bin.
taskbody.postreq:
Set or Class types in a Selected state will remain so until either:
The drawer of the Set or Class type is clicked a second time to Deselect it.
The nodes are Discarded.

link.desc: Use the Select function to choose which nodes to execute a command on.
The All function is used to perform actions on all nodes at the same time.
Select nodes by hand with the following steps.
Select nodes using the Like bar to perform a text search.
It is easy to tell the difference between Selected from Unselected nodes.

task.title: Select by Search
task.shortdesc: Select nodes using the Like bar to perform a text search.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

context.p: The Like function searches the node names in the Dataset for textual matches. Matching nodes are then selected to execute a Command.The Like bar offers full Regex power. For example, searching "19\d\d" will return matches for numbers in the range 1900-1999.ONLY the node names are searched. The Like function does NOT perform searches on other features like Set/Class types or Snippet text.

step.cmd: Type a search term into the Like bar.
Click a Set or Class type to choose a category of nodes to perform the search on.
step.info: To search all nodes for matches, click All under Sets.
Notice that the Current Command will update to reflect the Search term and selected Set/Class type.

step.cmd: Click on the desired Verb to choose an action.

taskbody.result: In this example, the user searched for ALL nodes LIKE "University" and then executed the VERB Activate. As a result, nodes with names containing "University" were pulled into the graph.

task.title: Retrieve in Commands Tab
task.shortdesc: Return Discarded nodes to the Shelf using the Commands Tab.

context.p:
To Retrieve all Discarded nodes at once use the following steps:
Click on the Discarded drawer in the Sets bin.
Click Retrieve
To Retrieve a specific Class of nodes from the Discard bin use the following steps:

step.cmd: Click on the desired Class type in the Classes bin.
step.info: Note that clicking on a Class type automatically Selects those nodes for future actions, as indicated by their bold appearance.

step.cmd: Under Verbs, click Retrieve.

taskbody.result: In this example, the function Retrieve was executed on the Class Type "Person." As a result, the Person node in the Discard Bin, labelled "Jules Verne," was returned to the Shelf. However, the Person nodes in the central Graph remained untouched.

link.desc: Use the Retrieve function to return only Discarded nodes to the Shelf.
The Discard function removes nodes from the central Graph or Shelf and sends them to the Discard bin.
Discard nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
In the Commands Tab, actions are automatically executed when a selected Set or Class type is combined with a Verb.

conbody.p: Once removed, Hidden nodes will be no longer appear in either the central Graph, Shelf or Discard bin.However, Hidden nodes are not permanently deleted from the dataset and can be retrieved using the Commands Tab.Unlike most other Verbs, this function cannot be executed directly in the Graph. To Hide nodes, the user must execute the Verb in the Commands Tab.

topic.title: Pin
topic.shortdesc: The Pin function fixes or "pins" Graphed nodes in place.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

body.p: By default, networks of graphed nodes float freely within the central stage. However, there are times when working with a static graph is preferable.
Using the Pin function, the branches of a node network can be stretched out and fixed in place.
body.note: Only graphed nodes can be pinned. The Pin function cannot be executed on nodes that are in a shelved or discarded state.
Graphed nodes can be Pinned in any area that is not designated as part of the Shelf or Discard Bin. This includes the area both inside and outside the central ring.

link.desc: Pin nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
In the Commands Tab, actions are automatically executed when a selected Set or Class type is combined with a Verb.

concept.title: Edges
concept.shortdesc: When two nodes in the central Graph are linked together by a line this indicates that they share a relationship. The nature of this relationship is represented as an Edge.

conbody.p: RDF-syntax distinguishes between the visual representation of a relationship in a graph and the textual representation as it is encoded in XML. The term "Edge" refers exclusively to graphs, while the term "Predicate" refers to a relationship as it is expressed through a Subject-Predicate-Object RDF triple-statement.
conbody.example:
In this case, Augusta Ada Byron is connected to Lord Byron by the Edge hasFather.
This is a visual representation of the RDF triple statement: <Byron, Augusta Ada> <hasFather> <LordByron>.

link.desc: Edges are displayed both in the Graph and in the Commands Tab.
Snippet windows allow users to explore the relationships between nodes in more detail. In the HuViz prototype, the "snippet" of text is extracted from the source entry on the Orlando Project.
Graph nodes according to the type of connections (aka Edges) they share using the Edges of Selected Nodes bin.

Clicking on the "deathConnectionToRegion" drawer in the EdgesofSelectedNodes bin dragged those regions (Nottinghamshire and Middlesex) into the central Graph.

concept.title: Settings Tab
concept.shortdesc: Adjust the appearance of the graph using the Settings Tab.

conbody.note: When working with large datasets, adjust the Shelf Radius, Fisheye Zoom and Fisheye Radius to separate the distance between nodes and "zoom in" on individual nodes.

row.entry: ELEMENT
DESCRIPTION
Adjust font size of Node labels in hover mode.
Adjust size of Selected Nodes; helps user see which Nodes will be effected by actions in the CommandsTab.
Adjust size of All Nodes for easier viewing.
Adjust font size of All Node labels.
Adjust font size of text body in Snippet Window.
Adjust font size of Triple (statement describing the subject, object and predicate); the Triple appears as a title above the text body in Snippet Window.
Adjust the attraction and repulsion between graphed nodes, similar to a magnetic charge.
Controls whether graphed nodes are fixed in the centre OR float free.
Adjust Shelf circumference; controls the size of the orbit containing ungraphed Nodes.
Control magnification strength of cursor.
Control magnification scope of cursor; increased scope provides immersive 3D view of graph.
Adjust length of links between graphed Nodes.
Adjust thickness of links between graphed Nodes
Increases the variation in link thickness according to the number of shared connections, with thicker lines havin a higher Edge count.
Adjust the curvature of links to seperate or collapse multiple Edges.
Display the number of connections in the Edge label.
